License: CC BY 4.0
arXiv:2410.03706v1 [cs.LG] 25 Sep 2024

Topological Foundations of Reinforcement Learning

Krame Kadurha David
david.krame@aims-cameroon.org
African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS)
Cameroon
Supervised by: Dr. Ya√© U. Gaba
AIMS-Research & Innovation Center (AIMS RIC)
Kigali, Rwanda
(18 May 2024
Submitted in Partial Fulfillment of a Structured Masters Degree at AIMS-Cameroon )

Abstract

The goal of this work is to serve as a foundation for deep studies of the topology of state, action, and policy spaces in reinforcement learning. By studying these spaces from a mathematical perspective, we expect to gain more insight into how to build better algorithms to solve decision problems. Therefore, we focus on presenting the connection between the Banach fixed point theorem and the convergence of reinforcement learning algorithms, and we illustrate how the insights gained from this can practically help in designing more efficient algorithms. Before doing so, however, we first introduce relevant concepts such as metric spaces, normed spaces and Banach spaces for better understanding, before expressing the entire reinforcement learning problem in terms of Markov decision processes. This allows us to properly introduce the Banach contraction principle in a language suitable for reinforcement learning, and to write the Bellman equations in terms of operators on Banach spaces to show why reinforcement learning algorithms converge. Finally, we show how the insights gained from the mathematical study of convergence are helpful in reasoning about the best ways to make reinforcement learning algorithms more efficient.

Keywords : Markov Decision Process; Reinforcement Learning; Contraction mapping; Fixed Point; Banach Space; Bellman Operators; Q-Learning.

Declaration

I, the undersigned, hereby declare that the work contained in this essay is my original work, and that any work done by others or by myself previously has been acknowledged and referenced accordingly.

 Krame Kadurha David, 18 May 2024.

Chapter 1 Introduction

There is not much work on the foundations of Reinforcement Learning (RL). Especially from a topological point of view. This work is, to the best of our knowledge, the first attempt to unify the basic concepts of Reinforcement Learning in a coherent and well-ordered way, specifying all the underlying mathematical concepts.

Some researchers have instead been interested in related questions, trying to explore RL concepts from a mathematical point of view, with the aim of improving the effectiveness of RL algorithms. For example:

In the paper [12], the authors studied the geometric and topological properties of the value functions in Markov decision processes with finite number of states and actions. Their characterization of the value function space as a general polytope provides an understanding of the relationships between policies and value functions. This perspective enhances the theoretical understanding of RL dynamics. The authors of [5] also explored the concept of Lipschitz continuity in model-based RL, emphasizing the importance of learning Lipschitz continuous models for efficient value function estimation. This establishes some error bounds and demonstrates the benefits of controlling the Lipschitz constant in RL setting. The work done in [34] extends model-free RL algorithms to continuous state-action spaces using a Q-learning-based approach, and that advancement opens avenues for applying RL techniques to a broader range of real-world applications with continuous state spaces. A very deep study is then done in [21], introducing a unified formalism for defining state similarity metrics in RL. The authors claim to address the challenge of generalization in continuous-state systems by establishing hierarchies among metrics and examining their implications on RL algorithms.
The aforementioned works can be difficult to understand or even less precise if the foundations are not well clarified. Therefore, the main goal of our work is to serve as a first stone in studying and organising the basic concepts, while presenting Reinforcement Learning in a simple and concise way, to help future researchers to quickly dive into the foundations of RL and to study more deeply, in particular the topology of state, action, and policy spaces. By studying these spaces from a mathematical perspective, we expect to gain more insight into how to build better algorithms to solve decision problems.
At the end of this work, we even illustrate the latter assumption by showing that, with the mathematical investigation we have done, we are able to make very strong and general conjectures which merit to be taken seriously into account. This work is organized then as follows :

After this introduction, in chapter 2, we discuss metric spaces and their completeness, as well as the Banach Fixed Point Theorem. We end the chapter giving an application of the Banach Fixed Point Theorem to a concrete example.

In chapter 3, we formally present the Markov Decision Process framework and directly after that, we present the concept of optimality in Reinforcement Learning. At the end, we then discuss some methods which are at the core of how optimality is attained in Reinforcement Learning.

In chapter 4, we express reinforcement in term of Operators to have a simple way of proving why Reinforcement Learning Algorithms work, using the Banach Contraction Principle. In fact, this chapter discusses about Bellman Operators and shows how the optimality can be reached using operators‚Äô language.

Finally, before the final conclusion, in chapter 5 we present some limitations of the classical Bellman operator and, using some insights gained from the mathematical investigation done before, we propose an alternative to the classical Bellman operator which shows good behaviour in terms of optimality and efficiency.

Chapter 2 Metric spaces and the Banach fixed point

In this chapter, we present the fundamental concepts of metric spaces and explore their completeness, a crucial property in understanding the behavior of sequences within these spaces. We also study the Banach fixed point theorem, a result which establishes the existence and uniqueness of fixed points for mappings in complete metric spaces. We elucidate the significance of this theorem in providing a theoretical foundation for iterative algorithms and solution techniques in various mathematical and computational contexts. Furthermore, we culminate our discussion by illustrating the practical relevance of the Banach Fixed Point Theorem through a concrete example, demonstrating its applicability in solving real-world problems and providing insight into its computational implications.

2.1 Complete metric spaces

Metrics and metric spaces provide a structured framework for precisely measuring the relationship between elements within a set. This facilitates deeper insights into their interconnections and dependencies, enabling pattern recognition, association identification, and informed decision-making across diverse domains. In this section, we delve into complete metric spaces, which offer a comprehensive framework for understanding the entirety of a set‚Äôs elements and their interrelations.

2.1.1 Definition (Metric and metric space).

A metric on a set MùëÄMitalic_M is a function d:M√óM‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëë‚ÜíùëÄùëÄ‚Ñùd:M\times M\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_d : italic_M √ó italic_M ‚Üí blackboard_R, such that for x,y,z‚ààMùë•ùë¶ùëßùëÄx,y,z\in Mitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ‚àà italic_M:

  • (i)

    [Non-negativity] d‚Å¢(x,y)‚â•0ùëëùë•ùë¶0d(x,y)\geq 0italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ‚â• 0 and d‚Å¢(x,x)=0ùëëùë•ùë•0d(x,x)=0italic_d ( italic_x , italic_x ) = 0

  • (ii)

    [Identity of indiscernibles] d‚Å¢(x,y)=0‚üπx=yùëëùë•ùë¶0ùë•ùë¶d(x,y)=0\implies x=yitalic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 0 ‚üπ italic_x = italic_y

  • (iii)

    [Symmetry] d‚Å¢(x,y)=d‚Å¢(y,x)ùëëùë•ùë¶ùëëùë¶ùë•d(x,y)=d(y,x)italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_d ( italic_y , italic_x )

  • (iv)

    [Triangle Inequality] d‚Å¢(x,y)‚â§d‚Å¢(x,z)+d‚Å¢(z,y)ùëëùë•ùë¶ùëëùë•ùëßùëëùëßùë¶d(x,y)\leq d(x,z)+d(z,y)italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ‚â§ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_z ) + italic_d ( italic_z , italic_y )

The pair (M,d)ùëÄùëë(M,d)( italic_M , italic_d ) is called a metric space.

Let‚Äôs now give some interesting examples of metric spaces.

    dp‚Å¢(x,y)=(‚àëi=1n|xi‚àíyi|p)1/p‚Å¢with‚Å¢p‚â•1subscriptùëëùëùùë•ùë¶superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëù1ùëùwithùëù1d_{p}(x,y)=\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|x_{i}-y_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}~{}~{}~{}\text{% with}~{}~{}p\geq 1italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with italic_p ‚â• 1

    The conditions (i), (ii) and (iii) hold due to the properties of the absolute value and the triangle inequality also holds because it is the result of the Minkowsky‚Äôs inequality [19, 20]. Indeed assuming that ai=xi‚àízisubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëßùëña_{i}=x_{i}-z_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bi=zi‚àíyisubscriptùëèùëñsubscriptùëßùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñb_{i}=z_{i}-y_{i}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write the triangle inequality as follows :

    (‚àëi=1n|ai+bi|p)1/p‚â§(‚àëi=1n|ai|p)1/p+(‚àëi=1n|bi|p)1/psuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëèùëñùëù1ùëùsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëñùëù1ùëùsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëñùëù1ùëù\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|a_{i}+b_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}\leq\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|a% _{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}+\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|b_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (2.1.1)

    So, (‚Ñùn,dp)superscript‚Ñùùëõsubscriptùëëùëù\Big{(}\mathbb{R}^{n},d_{p}\Big{)}( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a metric space. When p=1ùëù1p=1italic_p = 1 we get the manhattan distance, if p=2ùëù2p=2italic_p = 2 we have the classical euclidian distance. But one case which is for a particular interest in this work is the case when p‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëùp\to\inftyitalic_p ‚Üí ‚àû. We get the infinity distance :

    d‚àû‚Å¢(x,y)=max1‚â§i‚â§n‚Å¢|xi‚àíyi|subscriptùëëùë•ùë¶1ùëñùëõsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñd_{\infty}(x,y)=\underset{1\leq i\leq n}{\max}~{}|x_{i}-y_{i}|italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = start_UNDERACCENT 1 ‚â§ italic_i ‚â§ italic_n end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (2.1.2)
  • 2)

    Let SùëÜSitalic_S be any non-empty set and B‚Å¢(S)ùêµùëÜB(S)italic_B ( italic_S ), the space of all bounded real-valued functions on SùëÜSitalic_S. Consider fùëìfitalic_f and gùëîgitalic_g in B‚Å¢(S)ùêµùëÜB(S)italic_B ( italic_S ), and define :

    d‚Å¢(f,g)=s‚Å¢u‚Å¢px‚ààS‚Å¢|f‚Å¢(x)‚àíg‚Å¢(x)|ùëëùëìùëîùë•ùëÜùë†ùë¢ùëùùëìùë•ùëîùë•d(f,g)=\underset{x\in S}{sup}~{}|f(x)-g(x)|italic_d ( italic_f , italic_g ) = start_UNDERACCENT italic_x ‚àà italic_S end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG italic_s italic_u italic_p end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_g ( italic_x ) | (2.1.3)

    The pair (B‚Å¢(S),d)ùêµùëÜùëë\Big{(}B(S),d\Big{)}( italic_B ( italic_S ) , italic_d ) is a metric space. This metric is called the supremum metric or uniform metric [20].

Having presented some interesting examples of metric spaces, we give some definitions and propositions, necessary to introduce the completeness of metric spaces.

2.1.3 Definition (Sequences).

A sequence in a metric space (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) is a function u:‚Ñï‚ÜíX:ùë¢‚Üí‚Ñïùëãu:\mathbb{N}\to Xitalic_u : blackboard_N ‚Üí italic_X. It can be written {un}n‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëõùëõ‚Ñï\{u_{n}\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚àà blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or just {un}subscriptùë¢ùëõ\{u_{n}\}{ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

2.1.4 Definition (Convergence).

A sequence {xn}subscriptùë•ùëõ\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of points in (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) is said to be convergent if there is a point x‚àó‚ààXsuperscriptùë•ùëãx^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X such that, for any Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0italic_Œµ > 0, there exists a positive integer N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that d‚Å¢(xn,x‚àó)<Œµùëësubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•ùúÄd(x_{n},x^{*})<\varepsilonitalic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < italic_Œµ whenever n>N0ùëõsubscriptùëÅ0n>N_{0}italic_n > italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The point x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is termed the limit of the sequence and we write xn‚Üíx‚àó‚Üísubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•x_{n}\rightarrow x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.1.5 Proposition.

The limit of a sequence in a metric space is unique.

Proof.

The proof of that can be seen in [31]. It leverages the property that metric spaces belong to the family of T2subscriptùëá2T_{2}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (or Hausdorff) topological spaces ‚àé

Cauchy sequences play a fundamental role in the study of completeness within metric spaces. A sequence is considered Cauchy if, for any arbitrarily small positive distance, there exists a point in the sequence beyond which all subsequent points are within that distance from each other. Completeness, on the other hand, refers to the property of a metric space wherein every Cauchy sequence converges to a limit within the space itself. Together, Cauchy sequences and completeness provide essential tools for understanding the convergence behavior and structural integrity of metric spaces.

2.1.6 Definition (Cauchy sequences).

A sequence {xn}subscriptùë•ùëõ\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in a metric space (X,d)ùëãùëë\Big{(}X,d\Big{)}( italic_X , italic_d ) is called a Cauchy sequence if for any given Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0italic_Œµ > 0, we can find N0‚àà‚ÑïsubscriptùëÅ0‚ÑïN_{0}\in\mathbb{N}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_N such that whenever min‚Å°{m,n}>N0ùëöùëõsubscriptùëÅ0\min\{m,n\}>N_{0}roman_min { italic_m , italic_n } > italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have

d‚Å¢(xm,xn)<Œµ.ùëësubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëõùúÄd(x_{m},x_{n})<\varepsilon.italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < italic_Œµ .

While every convergent sequence is a Cauchy sequence, the reverse of this is only true in ‚Äòcomplete metric spaces‚Äô.

2.1.7 Definition (Completeness).

The metric space (X,d)ùëãùëë\Big{(}X,d\Big{)}( italic_X , italic_d ) is said complete if every Cauchy sequence converges in XùëãXitalic_X.

2.1.8 Example.

Using the standard metric (absolute value), ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R is complete. Using also the associated standard metric, ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is complete [20].

2.1.9 Definition (Uniformly Cauchy sequence of functions).

We say that a sequence fn:X‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëõ‚Üíùëã‚Ñùf_{n}:X\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_X ‚Üí blackboard_R is uniformly Cauchy if for a given Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0italic_Œµ > 0, there exists N‚àà‚ÑïùëÅ‚ÑïN\in\mathbb{N}italic_N ‚àà blackboard_N with the following property:

|fn‚Å¢(x)‚àífm‚Å¢(x)|<Œµ‚Å¢for all‚Å¢x‚ààX‚Å¢and for all‚Å¢m,n‚â•N.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëõùë•subscriptùëìùëöùë•ùúÄfor allùë•ùëãand for allùëöùëõùëÅ|f_{n}(x)-f_{m}(x)|<\varepsilon~{}~{}\text{for all}~{}~{}x\in X~{}~{}\text{and% for all}~{}~{}m,n\geq N.| italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) | < italic_Œµ for all italic_x ‚àà italic_X and for all italic_m , italic_n ‚â• italic_N .

Normed spaces are a subset of metric spaces, where vectors have associated norms. They are useful because they provide a framework for measuring distances and magnitudes in vector spaces, aiding in the analysis of mathematical structures.

2.1.10 Definition (Norms and normed spaces).

Let‚Äôs VùëâVitalic_V be a linear space over a field ùïÇùïÇ\mathbb{K}blackboard_K. A norm on VùëâVitalic_V is a map ||‚ãÖ||:V√óV‚Üí‚Ñù+||\cdot||:V\times V\to\mathbb{R}^{+}| | ‚ãÖ | | : italic_V √ó italic_V ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for any x,y‚ààVùë•ùë¶ùëâx,y\in Vitalic_x , italic_y ‚àà italic_V and Œ±‚ààùïÇùõºùïÇ\alpha\in\mathbb{K}italic_Œ± ‚àà blackboard_K :

  • (i)

    [Positivity] ‚Äñx‚Äñ>0normùë•0~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}||x||>0| | italic_x | | > 0 for every x‚â†0ùë•0x\neq 0italic_x ‚â† 0

  • (ii)

    [Homogeneity] ‚ÄñŒ±‚Å¢x‚Äñ=|Œ±|‚Å¢‚Äñx‚Äñnormùõºùë•ùõºnormùë•~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}||\alpha x||=|\alpha|||x||| | italic_Œ± italic_x | | = | italic_Œ± | | | italic_x | |

  • (iii)

    [Triangle inequality] ‚Äñx+y‚Äñ‚â§‚Äñx‚Äñ+‚Äñy‚Äñnormùë•ùë¶normùë•normùë¶~{}~{}||x+y||\leq||x||+||y||| | italic_x + italic_y | | ‚â§ | | italic_x | | + | | italic_y | |

The pair (V,||‚ãÖ||)\Big{(}V,||\cdot||\Big{)}( italic_V , | | ‚ãÖ | | ) is called a normed space.

2.1.11 Remark.

While normed spaces focus on vector spaces and their associated norms, metric spaces provide a broader context for studying distances and relationships between points in arbitrary sets. If ||‚ãÖ||||\cdot||| | ‚ãÖ | | is a norm, we can get a metric dùëëditalic_d from it by doing d‚Å¢(x,y)=‚Äñx‚àíy‚Äñùëëùë•ùë¶normùë•ùë¶d(x,y)=||x-y||italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = | | italic_x - italic_y | |. This is called an induced metric.

2.1.12 Example.

Let XùëãXitalic_X be any nonempty set. Let us consider the linear space B‚Å¢(X)ùêµùëãB(X)italic_B ( italic_X ) of all bounded real valued functions on XùëãXitalic_X under the sup norm ||‚ãÖ||‚àû||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In B‚Å¢(X)ùêµùëãB(X)italic_B ( italic_X ), a sequence {fn}subscriptùëìùëõ\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is Cauchy if and only if it is uniformly Cauchy.

Proof.

Detailed proof in [38]. ‚àé

Banach spaces are a special class of normed vector spaces that are also complete metric spaces. This property of completeness ensures that every Cauchy sequence in the space will converge to a limit within the space itself, making Banach spaces crucial in various areas of analysis and functional analysis. Let now define the concept of Banach Space which will be important in the last chapter.

2.1.13 Definition.

A Banach space is a complete normed space.

2.1.14 Example.

The normed space (B(X),||‚ãÖ||‚àû)\left(B(X),||\cdot||_{\infty}\right)( italic_B ( italic_X ) , | | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as defined in the Example 2.1.12 is a Banach space.

Proof.

The proof can be found in [20]. We here just sketch it.
Let {fn}‚ààB‚Å¢(X)subscriptùëìùëõùêµùëã\{f_{n}\}\in B(X){ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ‚àà italic_B ( italic_X ) be a Cauchy sequence. By Example 2.1.12, the sequence {fn}subscriptùëìùëõ\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is uniformly Cauchy.

Let‚Äôs fix x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in Xitalic_x ‚àà italic_X and consider the sequence of scalars {fn‚Å¢(x)}subscriptùëìùëõùë•\{f_{n}(x)\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) }. Since ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R is complete, the sequence converges to a real number f‚Å¢(x)‚àà‚Ñùùëìùë•‚Ñùf(x)\in\mathbb{R}italic_f ( italic_x ) ‚àà blackboard_R.
First, we have to show that fùëìfitalic_f is bounded on XùëãXitalic_X and,
Secondly we have to show that {fn}subscriptùëìùëõ\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } converges uniformly to fùëìfitalic_f on XùëãXitalic_X. That will complete the proof. ‚àé

Metric spaces are not always complete. We here present a way to make complete an incomplete metric space.

2.1.15 Completion of Metric Spaces [20, 31]

Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a non-complete metric space. It is always possible to complete the space into a larger space in such a way that every Cauchy sequence in X has a limit in the completion. To do this, we should add new points to (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) and extend dùëëditalic_d to all these new points so that each non-convergent Cauchy sequences in XùëãXitalic_X find limits among these new points.

2.1.16 Definition (Completion).

Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space. A complete metric space (X‚àó,d‚àó)superscriptùëãsuperscriptùëë(X^{*},d^{*})( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is considered as a completion of the metric space (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) if :

  • (i)

    XùëãXitalic_X is a subspace of X‚àósuperscriptùëãX^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  • (ii)

    Every point of X‚àósuperscriptùëãX^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the limit of some sequence in XùëãXitalic_X

2.1.17 Theorem.

Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space. Then there exists a completion of (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ).

Proof.

For the proof, see [20]. ‚àé

Let us now present the contraction mapping and the Banach Contraction Principle. Those are the core concepts that we will use throughout the work.

2.2 Contraction mapping and fixed-point

2.2.1 Definition.

Let XùëãXitalic_X be an nonempty set and f:X‚ÜíX:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëãf:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X be a mapping on that set :

  • -

    A point xùë•xitalic_x is said to be a fixed point of fùëìfitalic_f if f‚Å¢(x)=xùëìùë•ùë•f(x)=xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x.

  • -

    We will write F‚Å¢i‚Å¢x‚Å¢(f)={x‚ààX:f‚Å¢(x)=x}ùêπùëñùë•ùëìconditional-setùë•ùëãùëìùë•ùë•Fix(f)=\{x\in X:f(x)=x\}italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f ) = { italic_x ‚àà italic_X : italic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x } the set of fixed points of fùëìfitalic_f on XùëãXitalic_X.

2.2.2 Proposition.

Let XùëãXitalic_X be a nonempty set and f:X‚ÜíX:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëãf:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X a mapping defined on it. If x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in Xitalic_x ‚àà italic_X is a unique fixed point of fnsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with fn=f‚àòf‚àò‚ãØ‚àòf‚èün‚àít‚Å¢i‚Å¢m‚Å¢e‚Å¢ssuperscriptùëìùëõùëõùë°ùëñùëöùëíùë†‚èüùëìùëì‚ãØùëìf^{n}=\underset{n-times}{\underbrace{f\circ f\circ\cdots\circ f}}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_UNDERACCENT italic_n - italic_t italic_i italic_m italic_e italic_s end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG under‚èü start_ARG italic_f ‚àò italic_f ‚àò ‚ãØ ‚àò italic_f end_ARG end_ARG for any n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1, then it is the unique fixed point of fùëìfitalic_f and reversely :

F‚Å¢i‚Å¢x‚Å¢(fn)={x}‚áîF‚Å¢i‚Å¢x‚Å¢(f)={x}iffùêπùëñùë•superscriptùëìùëõùë•ùêπùëñùë•ùëìùë•Fix(f^{n})=\{x\}\iff Fix(f)=\{x\}italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = { italic_x } ‚áî italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f ) = { italic_x }
Proof.

Let xùë•xitalic_x be a fixed point for fnsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in XùëãXitalic_X. Then we can write :

f‚Å¢(x)=f‚Å¢(fn‚Å¢(x))=fn+1‚Å¢(x)=fn‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(x))‚üπf‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢is a fixed point of‚Å¢fnùëìùë•ùëìsuperscriptùëìùëõùë•superscriptùëìùëõ1ùë•superscriptùëìùëõùëìùë•ùëìùë•is a fixed point ofsuperscriptùëìùëõf(x)=f\left(f^{n}(x)\right)=f^{n+1}(x)=f^{n}\left(f(x)\right)\implies~{}~{}f(x% )~{}~{}\text{is a fixed point of}~{}~{}f^{n}italic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_f ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) ) ‚üπ italic_f ( italic_x ) is a fixed point of italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Since xùë•xitalic_x is the only one fixed point for fnsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then f‚Å¢(x)=xùëìùë•ùë•f(x)=xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x, i.e. xùë•xitalic_x is also a fixed point for fùëìfitalic_f. Let‚Äôs now show that the aforementioned fixed point is unique also for fùëìfitalic_f :
Let‚Äôs take y‚â†xùë¶ùë•y\neq xitalic_y ‚â† italic_x another fixed point of fùëìfitalic_f, and compute y=f‚Å¢(y)=f2‚Å¢(y)=‚ãØ=fn‚Å¢(y)ùë¶ùëìùë¶superscriptùëì2ùë¶‚ãØsuperscriptùëìùëõùë¶y=f(y)=f^{2}(y)=\cdots=f^{n}(y)italic_y = italic_f ( italic_y ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) = ‚ãØ = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) or fn‚Å¢(y)=y‚áîy=xiffsuperscriptùëìùëõùë¶ùë¶ùë¶ùë•f^{n}(y)=y\iff y=xitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) = italic_y ‚áî italic_y = italic_x. Then, we‚Äôve clearly seen that xùë•xitalic_x is the unique fixed point for fùëìfitalic_f. ‚àé

Before stating the Banach Contraction Principle, let‚Äôs define all the important notions related to that specific theorem.

2.2.3 Definition.

[13, 14, 26, 29] Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space and f:X‚ÜíX:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëãf:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X a mapping on XùëãXitalic_X. fùëìfitalic_f is said to be Lipschitz continuous if there exist Œ±>0ùõº0\alpha>0italic_Œ± > 0 such that :

d‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(x),f‚Å¢(y))‚â§Œ±‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x,y)‚Å¢‚àÄx,y‚ààXformulae-sequenceùëëùëìùë•ùëìùë¶‚ãÖùõºùëëùë•ùë¶for-allùë•ùë¶ùëãd\left(f(x),f(y)\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x,y)~{}~{}~{}\forall x,y\in Xitalic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) ‚â§ italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ‚àÄ italic_x , italic_y ‚àà italic_X (2.2.1)
  • -

    If Œ±‚àà[0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in[0,1)italic_Œ± ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ), fùëìfitalic_f is said to be a contraction.

  • -

    If Œ±=1ùõº1\alpha=1italic_Œ± = 1 then fùëìfitalic_f is said non-expansive.

  • -

    If d‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(x),f‚Å¢(y))<d‚Å¢(x,y),‚àÄx‚â†yformulae-sequenceùëëùëìùë•ùëìùë¶ùëëùë•ùë¶for-allùë•ùë¶d\left(f(x),f(y)\right)<d(x,y),~{}\forall x\neq yitalic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) < italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) , ‚àÄ italic_x ‚â† italic_y then fùëìfitalic_f is contractive.

2.2.4 Proposition.

Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space and f:X‚ÜíX:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëãf:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X a contraction mapping with Œ±‚àà(0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_Œ± ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ). If fùëìfitalic_f has a fixed point, that point is unique.

Proof.

Suppose we have two fixed points xùë•xitalic_x and yùë¶yitalic_y for fùëìfitalic_f with always x‚â†yùë•ùë¶x\neq yitalic_x ‚â† italic_y. Because fùëìfitalic_f is a contraction, with Œ±‚àà(0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_Œ± ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) we can write :

0‚â†d‚Å¢(x,y)=d‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(x),f‚Å¢(y))‚â§Œ±‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x,y),0ùëëùë•ùë¶ùëëùëìùë•ùëìùë¶‚ãÖùõºùëëùë•ùë¶0\neq d(x,y)=d\left(f(x),f(y)\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x,y),0 ‚â† italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) ‚â§ italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ,

which is impossible (contradictory). So, the fixed point is unique. ‚àé

As we have now a formal definition of fixed point, contractions and some obvious implications, let‚Äôs now state the Banach Contraction Principle.

2.2.5 Theorem (Banach Contraction Principle : BCP [37]).

Let (X,d)ùëãùëë(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a complete metric space, f:X‚ÜíX:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëãf:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X a contraction. Then fùëìfitalic_f has a unique fixed point x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and for each x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in Xitalic_x ‚àà italic_X, limn‚Üí‚àûfn‚Å¢(x)=x‚àósubscript‚Üíùëõsuperscriptùëìùëõùë•superscriptùë•\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}f^{n}(x)=x^{*}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover,

d‚Å¢(fn‚Å¢(x),x‚àó)‚â§Œ±n1‚àíŒ±‚Å¢d‚Å¢(x,f‚Å¢(x)).ùëësuperscriptùëìùëõùë•superscriptùë•superscriptùõºùëõ1ùõºùëëùë•ùëìùë•d\left(f^{n}(x),x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}d\left(x,f(x)% \right).italic_d ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ± end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x , italic_f ( italic_x ) ) .

.

Proof.

Let us construct a sequence {xn}subscriptùë•ùëõ\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, starting on x0subscriptùë•0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and using the following recurrence :

xn=f‚Å¢(xn‚àí1)‚Å¢‚àÄn‚àà‚Ñï‚Å¢i.e.‚Å¢xn=fn‚Å¢(x0)subscriptùë•ùëõùëìsubscriptùë•ùëõ1for-allùëõ‚Ñïi.e.subscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùë•0x_{n}=f(x_{n-1})~{}~{}\forall n\in\mathbb{N}~{}~{}~{}\text{i.e.}~{}~{}~{}x_{n}% =f^{n}(x_{0})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àÄ italic_n ‚àà blackboard_N i.e. italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

We show that {xn}subscriptùë•ùëõ\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Cauchy-Sequence. In fact, since fùëìfitalic_f is a contraction, we should have :

d‚Å¢(xm+1,xm)ùëësubscriptùë•ùëö1subscriptùë•ùëö\displaystyle d(x_{m+1},x_{m})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =d‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(xm),f‚Å¢(xm‚àí1))‚â§Œ±‚ãÖd‚Å¢(xm,xm‚àí1)absentùëëùëìsubscriptùë•ùëöùëìsubscriptùë•ùëö1‚ãÖùõºùëësubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëö1\displaystyle=d\left(f(x_{m}),f(x_{m-1})\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x_{m},x_{m-1})= italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=Œ±‚ãÖd‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(xm‚àí1),f‚Å¢(xm‚àí2))‚â§Œ±2‚ãÖd‚Å¢(xm‚àí1,xm‚àí2)absent‚ãÖùõºùëëùëìsubscriptùë•ùëö1ùëìsubscriptùë•ùëö2‚ãÖsuperscriptùõº2ùëësubscriptùë•ùëö1subscriptùë•ùëö2\displaystyle=\alpha\cdot d\left(f(x_{m-1}),f(x_{m-2})\right)\leq\alpha^{2}% \cdot d(x_{m-1},x_{m-2})= italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚ãÆ‚ãÆ\displaystyle\vdots‚ãÆ
=Œ±m‚àí1‚ãÖd‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(x1),f‚Å¢(x0))‚â§Œ±m‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x1,x0)absent‚ãÖsuperscriptùõºùëö1ùëëùëìsubscriptùë•1ùëìsubscriptùë•0‚ãÖsuperscriptùõºùëöùëësubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•0\displaystyle=\alpha^{m-1}\cdot d\left(f(x_{1}),f(x_{0})\right)\leq\alpha^{m}% \cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})= italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2.2.2)

Now, for any given mùëömitalic_m and nùëõnitalic_n, positive and with n<mùëõùëön<mitalic_n < italic_m, the triangle inequality applied recursively gives :

d‚Å¢(xm,xn)ùëësubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëõ\displaystyle d(x_{m},x_{n})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§d‚Å¢(xm,xm‚àí1)+d‚Å¢(xm‚àí1,xm‚àí2)+‚ãØ+d‚Å¢(xn‚àí1,xn)absentùëësubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëö1ùëësubscriptùë•ùëö1subscriptùë•ùëö2‚ãØùëësubscriptùë•ùëõ1subscriptùë•ùëõ\displaystyle\leq d(x_{m},x_{m-1})+d(x_{m-1},x_{m-2})+\cdots+d(x_{n-1},x_{n})‚â§ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ‚ãØ + italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚â§(Œ±m‚àí1+Œ±m‚àí2+‚ãØ+Œ±n)‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x1,x0)‚Å¢from 2.2absent‚ãÖsuperscriptùõºùëö1superscriptùõºùëö2‚ãØsuperscriptùõºùëõùëësubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•0from 2.2\displaystyle\leq\left(\alpha^{m-1}+\alpha^{m-2}+\cdots+\alpha^{n}\right)\cdot d% (x_{1},x_{0})~{}~{}~{}\text{from \ref{eq : demons1}}‚â§ ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ‚ãØ + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from
‚â§Œ±n‚Å¢(Œ±m‚àín‚àí1+Œ±m‚àín‚àí2+‚ãØ+1)‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x1,x0)absent‚ãÖsuperscriptùõºùëõsuperscriptùõºùëöùëõ1superscriptùõºùëöùëõ2‚ãØ1ùëësubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•0\displaystyle\leq\alpha^{n}\left(\alpha^{m-n-1}+\alpha^{m-n-2}+\cdots+1\right)% \cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})‚â§ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ‚ãØ + 1 ) ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚â§Œ±n1‚àíŒ±‚ãÖd‚Å¢(x1,x0)absent‚ãÖsuperscriptùõºùëõ1ùõºùëësubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•0\displaystyle\leq\frac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}\cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ± end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2.2.3)

As we can now see from limn‚Üí‚àûŒ±n=0subscript‚Üíùëõsuperscriptùõºùëõ0\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\alpha^{n}=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 and d‚Å¢(x1,x0)ùëësubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•0d(x_{1},x_{0})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is fixed, we can say d‚Å¢(xm,xn)‚Üí0‚Üíùëësubscriptùë•ùëösubscriptùë•ùëõ0d(x_{m},x_{n})\to 0italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚Üí 0 as m,n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëöùëõm,n\to\inftyitalic_m , italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû. So, {xn}subscriptùë•ùëõ\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Cauchy sequence and since XùëãXitalic_X is complete, there exits only one x‚àó‚ààXsuperscriptùë•ùëãx^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X such that xn‚Üíx‚àó‚Üísubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•x_{n}\to x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So, by continuity of contractions, we can write :

x‚àó=limn‚Üí‚àûxn+1=limn‚Üí‚àûf‚Å¢(xn)=f‚Å¢(limn‚Üí‚àûxn)=f‚Å¢(limn‚Üí‚àûfn‚Å¢(x0))=f‚Å¢(x‚àó)superscriptùë•subscript‚Üíùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõ1subscript‚Üíùëõùëìsubscriptùë•ùëõùëìsubscript‚Üíùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõùëìsubscript‚Üíùëõsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùë•0ùëìsuperscriptùë•x^{*}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}x_{n+1}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}f(x_{n})=f\left(% \lim_{n\to\infty}x_{n}\right)=f\left(\lim_{n\to\infty}f^{n}(x_{0})\right)=f(x^% {*})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_f ( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_f ( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

And the proposition above (Proposition 2.2.2), we have a way to find this unique fixed point independently on the starting point.
And to show a good estimate of how we are approaching the limit we can rewrite the Expression 2.2 like this :

d‚Å¢(fn‚Å¢(x),x‚àó)‚â§Œ±n1‚àíŒ±‚Å¢d‚Å¢(x,f‚Å¢(x))‚â°d‚Å¢(xn,x‚àó)‚â§Œ±n1‚àíŒ±‚Å¢d‚Å¢(x0,x1)ùëësuperscriptùëìùëõùë•superscriptùë•superscriptùõºùëõ1ùõºùëëùë•ùëìùë•ùëësubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•superscriptùõºùëõ1ùõºùëësubscriptùë•0subscriptùë•1d\left(f^{n}(x),x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}d\left(x,f(x)% \right)~{}~{}~{}\equiv~{}~{}~{}d\left(x_{n},x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}% {1-\alpha}d\left(x_{0},x_{1}\right)italic_d ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ± end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x , italic_f ( italic_x ) ) ‚â° italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ± end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

‚àé

2.2.6 Remark.

The beauty of the Banach Contraction Principle is that it only require completeness for the metric space and contraction property on the mapping. Also, we can get closer and closer to the fixed point, starting from any point x‚â°x0‚ààXùë•subscriptùë•0ùëãx\equiv x_{0}\in Xitalic_x ‚â° italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X by just applying recursively the mapping on that specific point.

2.3 Application of the Banach Contraction Principle - An example

The Banach Fixed Point principle or Banach Contraction Principle (BCP) is very important in many fields, in mathematics as well as in its applications [3, 24, 38, 43]. We here introduce a problem whose solution is guaranteed by the Picard-Lindelof Theorem, the uniqueness of solutions of a first order Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE). We show that its solution can be obtained using the BCP.
Let‚Äôs say we have the following initial value problem (which is here an ODE with initial conditions) :

y‚Ä≤=F‚Å¢(x,y);y‚Å¢(x0)=y0‚Å¢with‚Å¢y‚Ä≤=d‚Å¢yd‚Å¢xformulae-sequencesuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùêπùë•ùë¶ùë¶subscriptùë•0subscriptùë¶0withsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùëëùë¶ùëëùë•y^{\prime}=F(x,y)~{}~{}~{};~{}~{}~{}y(x_{0})=y_{0}~{}~{}~{}\text{with}~{}~{}y^% {\prime}=\dfrac{dy}{dx}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) ; italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_d italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_x end_ARG (2.3.1)

This problem is in fact equivalent to the following :

y‚Å¢(x)‚àíy‚Å¢(x0)ùë¶ùë•ùë¶subscriptùë•0\displaystyle y(x)-y(x_{0})italic_y ( italic_x ) - italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,y‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëët‚Å¢as we have y0=y‚Å¢(x0)absentsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùë¶ùë°differential-dùë°as we have y0=y‚Å¢(x0)\displaystyle=\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y(t)\Big{)}dt~{}~{}\text{as we have $y% _{0}=y(x_{0})$}= ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t as we have italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚áíy‚Å¢(x)‚áíabsentùë¶ùë•\displaystyle\Rightarrow y(x)‚áí italic_y ( italic_x ) =y0+‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,y‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëëtabsentsubscriptùë¶0superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùë¶ùë°differential-dùë°\displaystyle=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y(t)\Big{)}dt= italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t (2.3.2)

So, the two problems 2.3.1 and 2.3.2 are exactly the same. And from this last Expression 2.3.2 we can define a sequence given by :

yn+1‚Å¢(x)=y0+‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,yn‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëët‚Å¢with y0=yn‚Å¢(x0)‚Å¢‚àÄn.subscriptùë¶ùëõ1ùë•subscriptùë¶0superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°subscriptùë¶ùëõùë°differential-dùë°with y0=yn‚Å¢(x0)‚Å¢‚àÄn.y_{n+1}(x)=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y_{n}(t)\Big{)}dt~{}~{}~{}\text{% with $y_{0}=y_{n}(x_{0})~{}~{}\forall~{}n$.}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t with italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àÄ italic_n . (2.3.3)

The problem can be seen as demonstrating the Picard-Lindelof Theorem which states the following :

2.3.1 Theorem (Picard-Lindelof Theorem [27]).

Let D‚äÇ‚Ñù√ó‚Ñùnùê∑‚Ñùsuperscript‚ÑùùëõD\subset\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_D ‚äÇ blackboard_R √ó blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be an open set, F:D‚Üí‚Ñùn:ùêπ‚Üíùê∑superscript‚ÑùùëõF:D\to\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_F : italic_D ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a continuous function and (x0,ùê≤0)‚ààDsubscriptùë•0subscriptùê≤0ùê∑(x_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0})\in D( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_D. Then the initial value problem

d‚Å¢ùê≤d‚Å¢x=y‚Ä≤=f‚Å¢(x,ùê≤),ùê≤‚Å¢(x0)=ùê≤0formulae-sequenceùëëùê≤ùëëùë•superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùëìùë•ùê≤ùê≤subscriptùë•0subscriptùê≤0\frac{d\mathbf{y}}{dx}=y^{\prime}=f(x,\mathbf{y}),\quad\mathbf{y}(x_{0})=% \mathbf{y}_{0}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_x end_ARG = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x , bold_y ) , bold_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

has a unique solution ùê≤‚Å¢(x)ùê≤ùë•\mathbf{y}(x)bold_y ( italic_x ) on closed intervals I=[x0‚àíŒµ,x0+Œµ]ùêºsubscriptùë•0ùúÄsubscriptùë•0ùúÄI=[x_{0}-\varepsilon,x_{0}+\varepsilon]italic_I = [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œµ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œµ ] with Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0italic_Œµ > 0.

To easily show the usefulness of the BCP for the problem 2.3.1, we can enunciate the Picard-Lindelof Theorem in especially the context of that problem as follows and then prove the existence and uniqueness of the solution :

2.3.2 Proposition.

[43]    Assume that :

  1. 1.

    With SùëÜSitalic_S a rectangle domain defined as follows

    S={(x,w)‚àà‚Ñù2:|x‚àíx0|‚â§a‚Å¢and‚Å¢|w‚àíy0|‚â§b}‚Å¢with a,b‚àà‚Ñù and w=y‚Å¢(x)ùëÜconditional-setùë•ùë§superscript‚Ñù2ùë•subscriptùë•0ùëéandùë§subscriptùë¶0ùëèwith a,b‚àà‚Ñù and w=y‚Å¢(x)S=\{(x,w)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}:|x-x_{0}|\leq a~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}|w-y_{0}|\leq b% \}~{}~{}\text{with $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$ and $w=y(x)$}italic_S = { ( italic_x , italic_w ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : | italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ‚â§ italic_a and | italic_w - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ‚â§ italic_b } with italic_a , italic_b ‚àà blackboard_R and italic_w = italic_y ( italic_x )

    The function F:S‚Üí‚Ñù:ùêπ‚ÜíùëÜ‚ÑùF:S\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : italic_S ‚Üí blackboard_R, given in the ODE 2.3.1 above, is continuous, and there exists c‚àà‚Ñù+ùëêsuperscript‚Ñùc\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_c ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that |F‚Å¢(x,y)|‚â§c.ùêπùë•ùë¶ùëê|F(x,y)|\leq c.| italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) | ‚â§ italic_c .

  2. 2.

    F‚Å¢(x,y)ùêπùë•ùë¶F(x,y)italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) satisfies the Lipschitz condition with respect to yùë¶yitalic_y on SùëÜSitalic_S, i.e. there exists L‚â•0ùêø0L\geq 0italic_L ‚â• 0 such that :

    |F‚Å¢(x,y1‚Å¢(x))‚àíF‚Å¢(x,y2‚Å¢(x))|‚â§L‚ãÖ|y1‚Å¢(x)‚àíy2‚Å¢(x)|,for all‚Å¢(x,y1),(x,y2)‚ààSformulae-sequenceùêπùë•subscriptùë¶1ùë•ùêπùë•subscriptùë¶2ùë•‚ãÖùêøsubscriptùë¶1ùë•subscriptùë¶2ùë•for allùë•subscriptùë¶1ùë•subscriptùë¶2ùëÜ|F(x,y_{1}(x))-F(x,y_{2}(x))|\leq L\cdot|y_{1}(x)-y_{2}(x)|,~{}~{}~{}\text{for% all}~{}~{}(x,y_{1}),(x,y_{2})\in S| italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) - italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) | ‚â§ italic_L ‚ãÖ | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) | , for all ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_S
  3. 3.

    The real number h‚Ñéhitalic_h satisfies : 0<h‚â§a,h‚Å¢c‚â§b,h‚Å¢L‚â§1formulae-sequence0‚Ñéùëéformulae-sequence‚Ñéùëêùëè‚Ñéùêø10<h\leq a,~{}~{}hc\leq b,~{}~{}hL\leq 10 < italic_h ‚â§ italic_a , italic_h italic_c ‚â§ italic_b , italic_h italic_L ‚â§ 1

The following holds :

  • (i)

    The sequence {yn}subscriptùë¶ùëõ\{y_{n}\}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } constructed in Relation 2.3.3 converges to a certain function y‚àósubscriptùë¶y_{*}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • (ii)

    The initial value problem stated in 2.3.1 and equivalently in its integrale form given by the Expression 2.3.2 has a unique solution which is exactly y‚àósubscriptùë¶y_{*}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • (iii)

    For n‚àà‚Ñïùëõ‚Ñïn\in\mathbb{N}italic_n ‚àà blackboard_N and k:=h‚Å¢Lassignùëò‚Ñéùêøk:=hLitalic_k := italic_h italic_L we have the following estimates :

    • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

      ‚Äñyn‚àíy‚àó‚Äñ‚àû‚â§kn1‚àík‚ãÖ‚Äñy1‚àíy0‚Äñ‚àûsubscriptnormsubscriptùë¶ùëõsubscriptùë¶‚ãÖsuperscriptùëòùëõ1ùëòsubscriptnormsubscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶0||y_{n}-y_{*}||_{\infty}\leq\dfrac{k^{n}}{1-k}\cdot||y_{1}-y_{0}||_{\infty}| | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_k end_ARG ‚ãÖ | | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT see the last Expression 2.2.

    • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

      ‚Äñyn+1‚àíy‚àó‚Äñ‚àû‚â§k1‚àík‚ãÖ‚Äñyn+1‚àíyn‚Äñ‚àûsubscriptnormsubscriptùë¶ùëõ1subscriptùë¶‚ãÖùëò1ùëòsubscriptnormsubscriptùë¶ùëõ1subscriptùë¶ùëõ||y_{n+1}-y_{*}||_{\infty}\leq\dfrac{k}{1-k}\cdot||y_{n+1}-y_{n}||_{\infty}| | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_k end_ARG ‚ãÖ | | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

We will not prove this proposition explicitly. We will follow a process, inspired with the assumptions made in the Proposition 2.3.2 and that will help us to demonstrate immediately (i)i(\textit{i})( i ) and (ii)ii(\textit{ii})( ii ). The point (iii)iii(\textit{iii})( iii ) about the estimates will follow immediately, due to the Expression 2.2.

Proof.

Let RùëÖRitalic_R be the rectangular domain :

R={(x,w)‚àà‚Ñù2:|x‚àíx0|‚â§h‚Å¢and‚Å¢|w‚àíy0|‚â§h.c}‚Å¢with h,c‚àà‚Ñù and w=y‚Å¢(x)ùëÖconditional-setùë•ùë§superscript‚Ñù2formulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùë•0‚Ñéandùë§subscriptùë¶0‚Ñéùëêwith h,c‚àà‚Ñù and w=y‚Å¢(x)R=\{(x,w)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}:|x-x_{0}|\leq h~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}|w-y_{0}|\leq h% .c\}~{}~{}\text{with $h,c\in\mathbb{R}$ and $w=y(x)$}italic_R = { ( italic_x , italic_w ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : | italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ‚â§ italic_h and | italic_w - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ‚â§ italic_h . italic_c } with italic_h , italic_c ‚àà blackboard_R and italic_w = italic_y ( italic_x )

Following the assumptions made for this Proposition, we know that 0<h‚â§a,h‚Å¢c‚â§bformulae-sequence0‚Ñéùëé‚Ñéùëêùëè0<h\leq a,~{}~{}hc\leq b0 < italic_h ‚â§ italic_a , italic_h italic_c ‚â§ italic_b, i.e. R‚äÇSùëÖùëÜR\subset Sitalic_R ‚äÇ italic_S.
Let XùëãXitalic_X be the set of all real-valued continuous functions y=y‚Å¢(x)ùë¶ùë¶ùë•y=y(x)italic_y = italic_y ( italic_x ) on [x0‚àíh,x0+h]subscriptùë•0‚Ñésubscriptùë•0‚Ñé[x_{0}-h,x_{0}+h][ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_h , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_h ]. Then XùëãXitalic_X is a closed subset of the normed space ùíû‚Å¢([x0‚àíh,x0+h])ùíûsubscriptùë•0‚Ñésubscriptùë•0‚Ñé\mathcal{C}\left([x_{0}-h,x_{0}+h]\right)caligraphic_C ( [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_h , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_h ] ) with the sup norm ||‚ãÖ||‚àû||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
Let‚Äôs now define an operator (a functional) like this (inspired by the second formulation of our problem, given in 2.3.2) :

T:X‚Üí:ùëá‚Üíùëãabsent\displaystyle T:X\toitalic_T : italic_X ‚Üí Xùëã\displaystyle Xitalic_X
g‚Å¢(x)‚Ü¶maps-toùëîùë•absent\displaystyle g(x)\mapstoitalic_g ( italic_x ) ‚Ü¶ h‚Å¢(x)=T‚Å¢g=y0+‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,g‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëët‚Ñéùë•ùëáùëîsubscriptùë¶0superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùëîùë°differential-dùë°\displaystyle h(x)=Tg=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g(t)\Big{)}dtitalic_h ( italic_x ) = italic_T italic_g = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t (2.3.4)

Since

d‚Å¢(h‚Å¢(x),y0)=supùë•‚Å¢|‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,g‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëët|=‚Äñ‚à´x0xF‚Å¢(t,g‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢ùëët‚Äñ‚àû‚â§c‚Å¢(x‚àíx0)‚â§c‚ãÖh‚â§b,ùëë‚Ñéùë•subscriptùë¶0ùë•supremumsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùëîùë°differential-dùë°subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùëîùë°differential-dùë°ùëêùë•subscriptùë•0‚ãÖùëê‚Ñéùëèd\Big{(}h(x),y_{0}\Big{)}=\underset{x}{\sup}{\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g% (t)\Big{)}dt\right|}=\left|\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g(t)\Big{)}dt\right% |\right|_{\infty}\leq c(x-x_{0})\leq c\cdot h\leq b,italic_d ( italic_h ( italic_x ) , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = underitalic_x start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t | = | | ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_c ( italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ italic_c ‚ãÖ italic_h ‚â§ italic_b ,

we can say that the operator TùëáTitalic_T in 2.3.4 is well defined.
Now, we have to prove that this operator is a contraction mapping. For that, let‚Äôs take g,g1‚ààXùëîsubscriptùëî1ùëãg,g_{1}\in Xitalic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X. We‚Äôll have :

d‚Å¢(T‚Å¢g,T‚Å¢g1)=d‚Å¢(h,h1)=ùëëùëáùëîùëásubscriptùëî1ùëë‚Ñésubscript‚Ñé1absent\displaystyle d\left(Tg,Tg_{1}\right)=d(h,h_{1})=italic_d ( italic_T italic_g , italic_T italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_d ( italic_h , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ‚Äñ‚à´x0x(F‚Å¢(t,g‚Å¢(t))‚àíF‚Å¢(t,g1‚Å¢(t)))‚Å¢ùëët‚Äñ‚àûsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùêπùë°ùëîùë°ùêπùë°subscriptùëî1ùë°differential-dùë°\displaystyle~{}~{}\left|\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\Big{(}F\left(t,g(t)\right)-F% \left(t,g_{1}(t)\right)\Big{)}dt\right|\right|_{\infty}| | ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) - italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) italic_d italic_t | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚â§\displaystyle\leq‚â§ ‚à´x0x‚Äñ(F‚Å¢(t,g‚Å¢(t))‚àíF‚Å¢(t,g1‚Å¢(t)))‚Äñ‚àû‚Å¢ùëëtsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•subscriptnormùêπùë°ùëîùë°ùêπùë°subscriptùëî1ùë°differential-dùë°\displaystyle~{}~{}\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\left|\left|\Big{(}F\left(t,g(t)\right)-F% \left(t,g_{1}(t)\right)\Big{)}\right|\right|_{\infty}dt‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ( italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) - italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_t
‚â§\displaystyle\leq‚â§ L‚ãÖ‚à´x0x|g‚Å¢(t)‚àíg1‚Å¢(t)|‚Å¢ùëët‚Å¢ using the second assumption.‚ãÖùêøsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•0ùë•ùëîùë°subscriptùëî1ùë°differential-dùë° using the second assumption.\displaystyle~{}~{}L\cdot\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\left|g(t)-g_{1}(t)\right|dt\text{~{}% ~{}~{}using the second assumption.}italic_L ‚ãÖ ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_g ( italic_t ) - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) | italic_d italic_t using the second assumption.
‚â§\displaystyle\leq‚â§ L‚Å¢h‚ãÖd‚Å¢(g,g1)=k‚ãÖd‚Å¢(g,g1).‚ãÖùêø‚Ñéùëëùëîsubscriptùëî1‚ãÖùëòùëëùëîsubscriptùëî1\displaystyle~{}~{}Lh\cdot d\left(g,g_{1}\right)=k\cdot d\left(g,g_{1}\right).italic_L italic_h ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_k ‚ãÖ italic_d ( italic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (2.3.5)

In 2.3.5, from the third assumption, we know that k<1ùëò1k<1italic_k < 1, then the operator TùëáTitalic_T is a contraction.
Hence now TùëáTitalic_T is a contraction mapping and X is a closed subset of a metric space, XùëãXitalic_X is also a complete metric space and by the Banach Fixed Point principle, TùëáTitalic_T has one unique fixed point gùëîgitalic_g which is the exactly the unique solution to the given ODE. ‚àé

2.3.3 Example.

Consider the following first order initial value problem

x‚Ä≤‚Å¢(t)=12‚Å¢x‚Å¢(t)‚àít,x‚Å¢(0)=0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùë°12ùë•ùë°ùë°ùë•00x^{\prime}(t)=\frac{1}{2}x(t)-t,~{}~{}~{}~{}x(0)=0.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_t , italic_x ( 0 ) = 0 .

From the Picard-Lindelof Theorem above, we are sure that we‚Äôll get a solution, and to converge to it, we started with a random function and used an iterative approach, as suggested by the Banach contraction principle that we used to prove the theorem (through the Proposition 2.3.2). We obtained the following results :

In the Figure 2.1 we can see that the algorithm converges quickly to the true function (just after 5 iterations on [0,4]04[0,4][ 0 , 4 ]. To make it work, we implemented the operator 2.3.4 and used the same kind of iterative process as suggested by the Banach contraction principle. The full implementation we did, as well as the use of other methods for validation and stability, can be seen in our Github [1]. The Example 2.3.3 has also been treated in [16] and the interested reader can compare our results with those found in that article.

Chapter Conclusion

In this chapter we have discussed contraction mappings in a metric space and the Banach contraction principle (or Banach fixed point theorem). We have also shown how the theorem can be used to prove the existence and uniqueness of solutions to first-order ordinary differential equations with initial conditions, and even to find the solution. In the next chapter we will give an overview of Reinforcement Learning, which will help us to relate it to the theories introduced in this chapter.

Chapter 3 Overview on Reinforcement Learning

In this chapter, we will first formally present the Markov Decision Process framework and how it relates to Reinforcement Learning. Second, we will talk about optimality in Reinforcement Learning, and finally we will discuss some methods that are at the core of how optimality is realised in Reinforcement Learning.

3.1 Markov Decision Processes in the Reinforcement Learning setting

We here present a formal definition of the Markov Decision Process. But before that, we discuss about Markov Chain because it allows us to present the fact that, there are situations in which the previous observation contains all the information about the past, in such a way that we don‚Äôt need to look at the whole history.

3.1.1 Definition (Markov chain [22]).

Let ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S (a subset of ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for example) represent the state space. The discrete-time dynamic system {St}t‚àà‚Ñï‚ààùíÆsubscriptsubscriptùëÜùë°ùë°‚ÑïùíÆ\{S_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\in\mathcal{S}{ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚àà blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_S is a Markov chain if :

‚Ñô‚Å¢(St+1=s|St,St‚àí1,‚ãØ,S0)=‚Ñô‚Å¢(St+1=s|St),‚ÑôsubscriptùëÜùë°1conditionalùë†subscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëÜùë°1‚ãØsubscriptùëÜ0‚ÑôsubscriptùëÜùë°1conditionalùë†subscriptùëÜùë°\mathbb{P}(S_{t+1}=s|S_{t},S_{t-1},\cdots,S_{0})=\mathbb{P}(S_{t+1}=s|S_{t}),blackboard_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚ãØ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (3.1.1)

i.e. everything we need to predict (in probability) the future is contained in the current state (this is what we call Markov property). Given an initial state S0‚ààùíÆsubscriptùëÜ0ùíÆS_{0}\in\mathcal{S}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_S, a Markov chain is defined by the following transition probability :

p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s)=P‚Å¢r‚Å¢(St+1=s‚Ä≤|St=s).ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëÉùëüsubscriptùëÜùë°1conditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†p(s^{\prime}|s)=Pr(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}|S_{t}=s).italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ) . (3.1.2)

We can now clearly define the Markov Decision Process and related concepts, important for Reinforcement Learning.

3.1.2 Definition (Markov Decision Process [22, 32]).

Formally, an Markov Decision Process (MDP) is a 5-uplet ‚Ñ≥=‚ü®ùíÆ,ùíú,p,r,Œ≥‚ü©‚Ñ≥ùíÆùíúùëùùëüùõæ\mathcal{M}=\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},p,r,\gamma\ranglecaligraphic_M = ‚ü® caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_p , italic_r , italic_Œ≥ ‚ü© where :

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S represents the state space. It can be finite, countable infinite or continuous.

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùíúùíú\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A represents the action space which could also be finite, countable infinite or continuous.

  • ‚Ä¢

    p‚Å¢(s,a,s‚Ä≤)ùëùùë†ùëésuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤p(s,a,s^{\prime})italic_p ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the transition probability (called environment dynamics) defined by :

    p(s,a,s‚Ä≤)‚â°p(s‚Ä≤|s,a)=Pr(St+1=s‚Ä≤|St=s,At=a),p(s,a,s^{\prime})\equiv p(s^{\prime}|s,a)=Pr(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=% a),italic_p ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â° italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ) , (3.1.3)

    with s,s‚Ä≤‚ààùíÆùë†superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùíÆs,s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_s , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_S and a‚ààùíúùëéùíúa\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A. This represents the probability of observing a next state s‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when the action aùëéaitalic_a is taken in the state sùë†sitalic_s.

  • ‚Ä¢

    r‚Å¢(s,a,s‚Ä≤)ùëüùë†ùëésuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤r(s,a,s^{\prime})italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the reward function called also a reinforcement obtained when taking the action aùëéaitalic_a, in the state sùë†sitalic_s and the next state observed is s‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So :

    r:ùíÆ√óùíú√óùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëü‚ÜíùíÆùíúùíÆ‚Ñùr:\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_r : caligraphic_S √ó caligraphic_A √ó caligraphic_S ‚Üí blackboard_R
  • ‚Ä¢

    The transition probability pùëùpitalic_p and the reward function rùëüritalic_r defines the environment model.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Œ≥‚àà[0,1)ùõæ01\gamma\in[0,1)italic_Œ≥ ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ) is the discount factor used to define (let‚Äôs say for discrete time here for illustration) the expected cumulative reward :

    G=‚àët=0‚àûŒ≥t‚ãÖr‚Å¢(St,At,St+1).ùê∫superscriptsubscriptùë°0‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùë°ùëüsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°subscriptùëÜùë°1G=\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{t}\cdot r(S_{t},A_{t},S_{t+1}).italic_G = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

If we have a problem which can be modeled as an MDP, the goal is generally to maximize the quantity Gùê∫Gitalic_G by choosing at each time and for each state the action Atsubscriptùê¥ùë°A_{t}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That choice is defined by a function œÄ:ùíÆ‚ÜíŒî‚Å¢ùíú:ùúã‚ÜíùíÆŒîùíú\pi:\mathcal{S}\to\Delta\mathcal{A}italic_œÄ : caligraphic_S ‚Üí roman_Œî caligraphic_A called policy. Where Œî‚Å¢ùíúŒîùíú\Delta\mathcal{A}roman_Œî caligraphic_A represents a probability distribution under actions.

3.1.3 Definition (Policy or decision rule).

Policy is a mapping of states to actions, which can be :

  • ‚Ä¢

    Deterministic : in the same conditions, the same action is always chosen.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Stochastic : at each time, actions are only chosen with a certain probability. In this case the policy is a mapping from the state space to a probability distribution over actions.

The policy can also be varying as the time evolve (Non-stationary policy) or constant (Stationary policy).

We have given the foundational definitions, let us now reformulate everything in the Reinforcement Learning setting :

  1. 1.

    The agent-environment interface
    Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) are indeed a simple way to frame the problem of learning from interaction to achieve a goal. We are here define some important terms in the field of Reinforcement Learning :

    • ‚Ä¢

      The element that has to learn and make decisions is called agent.

    • ‚Ä¢

      Everything with which the agent interacts, including any entity outside the agent, is called the environment.

    • ‚Ä¢

      The agent and the environment are in constant interaction, the former selecting actions, the latter responding to those actions and presenting new situations to the agent. These new situations are called states of the environment.

    • ‚Ä¢

      The agent also receives rewards (special numerical values) from the environment and tries to maximise these over time through its choice of actions.

    • ‚Ä¢

      We call action the way the agent chooses to interact with its environment. Or simply, the interaction of the agent with its environment.

    Let us now call StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Atsubscriptùê¥ùë°A_{t}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and RtsubscriptùëÖùë°R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively the state, the action and the reward at a specific time-step tùë°titalic_t.The MDP and the agent will now produce the following kind of sequences :

    S0,A0,R1,S1,A1,R2,S2,A2,R3,‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜ0subscriptùê¥0subscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÜ1subscriptùê¥1subscriptùëÖ2subscriptùëÜ2subscriptùê¥2subscriptùëÖ3‚Ä¶S_{0},A_{0},R_{1}~{}~{},~{}~{}S_{1},A_{1},R_{2}~{}~{},~{}~{}S_{2},A_{2},R_{3}~% {}~{},...italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶

    The set of rewards, actions and states will be respectively written as ‚Ñõ,ùíú‚Ñõùíú\mathcal{R},\mathcal{A}caligraphic_R , caligraphic_A and ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. We‚Äôll also call ùíú‚Å¢(s)ùíúùë†\mathcal{A}(s)caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) the actions which are feasible in a specific state St=ssubscriptùëÜùë°ùë†S_{t}=sitalic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s.

    The Figure 3.1 shows schematically all the above concepts and how they are related.

  2. 2.

    Model of the environment
    Let us now suppose that we are able to have access to all the dynamic of our environment. Then, we can generally define a function which gives the probability of transiting in a certain state StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and receive a certain reward RtsubscriptùëÖùë°R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if we were previously in the state St‚àí1subscriptùëÜùë°1S_{t-1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and made the action At‚àí1subscriptùê¥ùë°1A_{t-1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That kind of function, defined for the whole action and state spaces is called the model of the environment. It can be generally defined as follows :

    p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚â°P‚Å¢r‚Å¢({St=s‚Ä≤,Rt=r|St‚àí1=s,At‚àí1=a})‚Å¢‚àÄs,s‚Ä≤‚ààùíÆ,r‚àà‚Ñõ;a‚ààùíú‚Å¢(s)formulae-sequenceùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëéùëÉùëüconditional-setformulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëÖùë°ùëüformulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°1ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°1ùëéfor-allùë†formulae-sequencesuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùíÆformulae-sequenceùëü‚Ñõùëéùíúùë†p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\equiv Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t}=s^{\prime},R_{t}=r|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1% }=a\}\Big{)}~{}\forall s,s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}~{},r\in\mathcal{R};~{}a\in% \mathcal{A}(s)italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚â° italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } ) ‚àÄ italic_s , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_S , italic_r ‚àà caligraphic_R ; italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) (3.1.4)

    Most of the time, it is assumed that, the next values depend only on the immediate previous values (Markov property) [22]. The Markov Property can be formalized as follows :

    p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)=P‚Å¢r‚Å¢({St,Rt|St‚àí1,At‚àí1,St‚àí2,At‚àí2,‚Ä¶})=P‚Å¢r‚Å¢({St=s‚Ä≤,Rt=r|St‚àí1=s,At‚àí1=a})ùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëéùëÉùëüconditional-setsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëÖùë°subscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùê¥ùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°2subscriptùê¥ùë°2‚Ä¶ùëÉùëüconditional-setformulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëÖùë°ùëüformulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°1ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°1ùëép(s^{\prime},r|s,a)=Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t},R_{t}|S_{t-1},A_{t-1},S_{t-2},A_{t-2},...% \}\Big{)}=Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t}=s^{\prime},R_{t}=r|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\}\Big{)}italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ } ) = italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } )

    This function defines the dynamic of a Markov decision process.

  3. 3.

    Other important definitions from the model of the environment
    MDPs are powerful tools for modeling and solving problems where decision making involves uncertainty and sequential actions. We are here giving other formal definitions which shows how we can derive well-known concepts from the general Definition given by the Expression 3.1.4 [36].

    1. (a)

      Second form of the environment model
      This definition is the commonly used but is not as general as the one we gave in Relation 3.1.4. The reward is not explicitly considered :

      p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚â°P‚Å¢r‚Å¢{St=s‚Ä≤|St‚àí1=s,At‚àí1=a}=‚àër‚àà‚Ñõp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùëÉùëüconditional-setsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùë†‚Ä≤formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°1ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°1ùëésubscriptùëü‚Ñõùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëép(s^{\prime}|s,a)\equiv Pr\left\{S_{t}=s^{\prime}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\right\}=% \sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚â° italic_P italic_r { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚àà caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) (3.1.5)
    2. (b)

      Definition of the reward
      Here we define the reward without considering the next state of the environment:

      r‚Å¢(s,a)‚â°ùîº‚Å¢[Rt|St‚àí1=s,At‚àí1=a]=‚àër‚àà‚Ñõ(r‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤‚ààùíÆp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a))ùëüùë†ùëéùîºdelimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscriptùëÖùë°subscriptùëÜùë°1ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°1ùëésubscriptùëü‚Ñõ‚ãÖùëüsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùíÆùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëér(s,a)\equiv\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\right]=\sum_{r\in% \mathcal{R}}\left(r\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\right)italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) ‚â° blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚àà caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ) (3.1.6)
    3. (c)

      Reward depending on next state
      Here we consider the next state in our definition of reward. That captures the most similar to our usual view of the reward function in real life:

      r‚Å¢(s,a,s‚Ä≤)‚â°ùîº‚Å¢[Rt|St‚àí1=s,At‚àí1=a,St=s‚Ä≤]=‚àër‚àà‚Ñõ(r‚ãÖp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a))ùëüùë†ùëésuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùîºdelimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscriptùëÖùë°subscriptùëÜùë°1ùë†formulae-sequencesubscriptùê¥ùë°1ùëésubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëü‚Ñõ‚ãÖùëüùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëéùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëér(s,a,s^{\prime})\equiv\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a,S_{t}=s^{% \prime}\right]=\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}\left(r\cdot\dfrac{p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)}{p% (s^{\prime}|s,a)}\right)italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â° blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚àà caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) end_ARG ) (3.1.7)
  4. 4.

    Formalization of the concepts of goals, rewards and returns
    In Reinforcement Learning (RL), the purpose or goal of the agent is formalized in terms of a special signal called a ‚Äúreward‚Äù as explained previously, which is sent to the agent from the environment. In other words, given the reward at any given time as just a real number, the ‚Äúgoal‚Äù of the agent is to maximize the total amount of rewards it receives. This is not a maximization of the immediate reward, but of the cumulative reward in the long run. With this in mind, if we call RtsubscriptùëÖùë°R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the reward we get at time tùë°titalic_t, we can generally define a function that we‚Äôll call return at that time like this :
