    Gt=Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖRt+2+Œ≥2‚ãÖRt+3+‚ãØ=‚àëk=0‚àûŒ≥k‚ãÖRt+k+1‚Å¢with‚Å¢Œ≥‚àà[0,1)subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÖùë°1‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùëÖùë°2‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæ2subscriptùëÖùë°3‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùëò0‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÖùë°ùëò1withùõæ01G_{t}=R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot R_{t+2}+\gamma^{2}\cdot R_{t+3}+\cdots=\sum_{k=0}^{% \infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}~{}~{}~{}\text{with}~{}~{}\gamma\in[0,1)italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚ãØ = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with italic_Œ≥ ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ) (3.1.8)

    In this Expression 3.1.8, the discount factor Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ can also be taken equal to one but this will lead to the divergence of the return function in infinite cases. This definition is mathematically consistent, and it is also consistent in real-life. In fact :

    • ‚Ä¢

      Mathematically : Taking Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ in the interval [0,1)01[0,1)[ 0 , 1 ) ensures the convergence of the series if only the reward function is bounded.

    • ‚Ä¢

      In real life : This definition of the return function is consistent with the concept that immediate rewards are more appreciated than rewards deferred into the future.

  5. 5.

    Policies and Value Functions
    Almost all RL algorithms involve estimating value functions, which are functions of states (or of state-action pairs) that estimate how good it is for an agent to be in a particular state (or to perform a particular action in a particular state).

    The reward that an agent can expect to receive in the future depends on which action will be taken. Accordingly, value functions are defined with respect to particular ways of acting, called policies. Formally, a policy is a mapping from states to action space. In general, it quantifies the probability of selecting a certain action in a specific state. So, the policy can be defined as follows:

    œÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚â°œÄ‚Å¢(At=a|St=s)=P‚Å¢r‚Å¢{a‚ààùíú‚Å¢(s)|s},ùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùúãsubscriptùê¥ùë°conditionalùëésubscriptùëÜùë°ùë†ùëÉùëüconditional-setùëéùíúùë†ùë†\pi\left(a|s\right)\equiv\pi\left(A_{t}=a|S_{t}=s\right)=Pr\left\{a\in\mathcal% {A}(s)|s\right\},italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ‚â° italic_œÄ ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r { italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) | italic_s } , (3.1.9)

    where ùíú‚Å¢(s)ùíúùë†\mathcal{A}(s)caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) represents the set of possible actions when we are in the state sùë†sitalic_s.
    The value function now, for a state sùë†sitalic_s, under a policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ, denoted vœÄ‚Å¢(s)subscriptùë£ùúãùë†v_{\pi}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ), is the expected payoff of starting in that state and then following that policy. For MDPs we can formally say that the value function is given by :

    vœÄ‚Å¢(s)‚â°ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[Gt|St=s]=ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[‚àëk=0‚àûŒ≥k‚ãÖRt+k+1|St=s]subscriptùë£ùúãùë†subscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùëò0‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÖùë°ùëò1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†v_{\pi}(s)\equiv\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}% \left[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}|S_{t}=s\right]italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ‚â° blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ] (3.1.10)

    We can similarly define the value function of taking an action aùëéaitalic_a while following the same policy, starting in the state sùë†sitalic_s, which is called the Q-value :

    qœÄ‚Å¢(s,a)‚â°ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[Gt|St=s,At=a]=ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[‚àëk=0‚àûŒ≥k‚ãÖRt+k+1|St=s,At=a]subscriptùëûùúãùë†ùëésubscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëésubscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùëò0‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÖùë°ùëò1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëéq_{\pi}(s,a)\equiv\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]=\mathbb{E% }_{\pi}\left[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) ‚â° blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] (3.1.11)

    The equations 3.1.10 and 3.1.11 correspond respectively to the state-value function and the action-value function. Also, the state value function can be seen as the average of all the values that can be achieved by acting from a given state, i.e., we can see the state value function as a weighted average of the action-value functions that we can obtain starting from that state. So, formally :

    vœÄ‚Å¢(s)‚â°‚àëa‚ààùíú‚Å¢(s)qœÄ‚Å¢(s,a)‚ãÖœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)subscriptùë£ùúãùë†subscriptùëéùíúùë†‚ãÖsubscriptùëûùúãùë†ùëéùúãconditionalùëéùë†v_{\pi}(s)\equiv\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}q_{\pi}(s,a)\cdot\pi(a|s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ‚â° ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) (3.1.12)

    Now the following holds between the value of sùë†sitalic_s and the value of its possible successor states for any policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ and any state sùë†sitalic_s :

    vœÄ‚Å¢(s)subscriptùë£ùúãùë†\displaystyle v_{\pi}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[Gt|St=s]absentsubscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s\right]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ]
    =ùîºœÄ‚Å¢[Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖGt+1|St=s]absentsubscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùë°1conditional‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùê∫ùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot G_{t+1}|S_{t}=s\right]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ]
    =‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚Å¢(‚àës‚Ä≤‚àërp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚Å¢[r+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºœÄ‚Å¢[Gt+1|St+1=s‚Ä≤]])absentsubscriptùëéùúãconditionalùëéùë†subscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëüùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëü‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºùúãdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùê∫ùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°1superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\left(\sum_{s^{\prime}}\sum_{r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,% a)\Big{[}r+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t+1}|S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}\right]% \Big{]}\right)= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) [ italic_r + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ] ) (3.1.13)
    ‚áívœÄ‚Å¢(s)‚áíabsentsubscriptùë£ùúãùë†\displaystyle\Rightarrow v_{\pi}(s)‚áí italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚Å¢(‚àës‚Ä≤,rp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚Å¢[r+Œ≥‚ãÖvœÄ‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)])absentsubscriptùëéùúãconditionalùëéùë†subscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëüùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëü‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£ùúãsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\left(\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\Big% {[}r+\gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\Big{]}\right)= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) [ italic_r + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ) (3.1.14)
    using then the equation 3.1.6
    ‚áívœÄ‚Å¢(s)‚áíabsentsubscriptùë£ùúãùë†\displaystyle\Rightarrow v_{\pi}(s)‚áí italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚ãÖ(r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚Å¢vœÄ‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤))absentsubscriptùëé‚ãÖùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptùë£ùúãsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(% s^{\prime}|s,a)v_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\right)= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ‚ãÖ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.1.15)

    The Relation 3.1.13 is explained by the definition of the reward function given by the equation 3.1.6, and also by the fact that we normally have to do a weighted summation under the action set ùíúùíú\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A to account for all actions. The equation 3.1.15 is then called Bellman equation for the value function vœÄsubscriptùë£ùúãv_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
    We can define in the same way the Bellman equation corresponding to the action-value function as follows [18] :

    qœÄ‚Å¢(s,a)=r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖ(‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ‚Å¢(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖqœÄ‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))subscriptùëûùúãùë†ùëéùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùúãconditionalsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëûùúãsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤q_{\pi}(s,a)=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot\left(% \sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot q_{\pi}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime}% )\right)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.1.16)

From now on we can notice that the MDP framework is a considerable abstraction of the problem of goal-directed learning from interaction.

3.2 Optimal Policies and Optimal Value Functions

Here we present the optimal value functions and discuss how they can be used to find the optimal policy [36]. In fact, the value function defines a partial ordering over policies. More precisely, given two policies œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ and œÄ‚Ä≤superscriptùúã‚Ä≤\pi^{\prime}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can say,

œÄ‚â•œÄ‚Ä≤‚áîvœÄ‚Å¢(s)‚â•vœÄ‚Ä≤‚Å¢(s)‚àÄs‚ààùíÆ,iffùúãsuperscriptùúã‚Ä≤formulae-sequencesubscriptùë£ùúãùë†subscriptùë£superscriptùúã‚Ä≤ùë†for-allùë†ùíÆ\pi\geq\pi^{\prime}\iff v_{\pi}(s)\geq v_{\pi^{\prime}}(s)~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}% \forall s\in\mathcal{S},italic_œÄ ‚â• italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚áî italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ‚â• italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ‚àÄ italic_s ‚àà caligraphic_S , (3.2.1)

but we are not always able to compare two value functions. So, the policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ is defined to be better than or equal to œÄ‚Ä≤superscriptùúã‚Ä≤\pi^{\prime}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if its expected return is greater than or equal to that of œÄ‚Ä≤superscriptùúã‚Ä≤\pi^{\prime}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all states.
And now, if œÄ‚àósuperscriptùúã\pi^{*}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal policy we have :

{v‚àó‚Å¢(s)‚â°maxùúã‚Å¢vœÄ‚Å¢(s)q‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)‚â°maxùúã‚Å¢qœÄ‚Å¢(s,a)=ùîº‚Å¢[Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖv‚àó‚Å¢(St+1)|St=s,At=a]casessubscriptùë£ùë†ùúãsubscriptùë£ùúãùë†subscriptùëûùë†ùëéùúãsubscriptùëûùúãùë†ùëéùîºdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÖùë°1conditional‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£subscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëé\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{lcl}v_{*}(s)&\equiv&\underset{\pi}{\max}~{% }v_{\pi}(s)\\ q_{*}(s,a)&\equiv&\underset{\pi}{\max}~{}q_{\pi}(s,a)=\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t+1}+% \gamma\cdot v_{*}(S_{t+1})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]\end{array}\right.{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_CELL start_CELL ‚â° end_CELL start_CELL underitalic_œÄ start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) end_CELL start_CELL ‚â° end_CELL start_CELL underitalic_œÄ start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (3.2.4)

3.2.1 Bellman optimality equation

Since we take the optimal action at each time (following the optimal policy œÄ‚àósuperscriptùúã\pi^{*}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), we can write v‚àó‚Å¢(s)=maxa‚ààùíú‚Å¢(s)‚Å¢qœÄ‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)subscriptùë£ùë†ùëéùíúùë†subscriptùëûsuperscriptùúãùë†ùëév_{*}(s)=\underset{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}{\max}~{}q_{\pi^{*}}(s,a)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = start_UNDERACCENT italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) , and this will be the best achievable expected reward at each time. So :

v‚àó‚Å¢(s)subscriptùë£ùë†\displaystyle v_{*}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =maxa‚ààùíú‚Å¢(s)‚Å¢qœÄ‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)absentùëéùíúùë†subscriptùëûsuperscriptùúãùë†ùëé\displaystyle=\underset{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}{\max}~{}q_{\pi^{*}}(s,a)= start_UNDERACCENT italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a )
=maxùëé‚Å¢ùîºœÄ‚àó‚Å¢[Gt|St=s,At=a]absentùëésubscriptùîºsuperscriptùúãdelimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëé\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s,A_{% t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=maxùëé‚Å¢ùîºœÄ‚àó‚Å¢[Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖGt+1|St=s,At=a]absentùëésubscriptùîºsuperscriptùúãdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÖùë°1conditional‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùê∫ùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëé\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma% \cdot G_{t+1}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=maxùëé‚Å¢ùîºœÄ‚àó‚Å¢[Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖv‚àó‚Å¢(St+1)|St=s,At=a]absentùëésubscriptùîºsuperscriptùúãdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÖùë°1conditional‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£subscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëé\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma% \cdot v_{*}(S_{t+1})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=maxùëé‚Å¢‚àës‚Ä≤,rp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚ãÖ[r+Œ≥‚ãÖv‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]absentùëésubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëü‚ãÖùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëü‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\cdot% \left[r+\gamma\cdot v_{*}(s^{\prime})\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ [ italic_r + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
=maxùëé‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚Å¢v‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]absentùëédelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)v_{*}(s^{\prime})\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] (3.2.5)

The Expression (3.2.5) follows the definition of the model of the environment given in point 2 on page 2. We can then show the consistency with the connection given in Expression (3.1.12) by deducing q‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)subscriptùëûùë†ùëéq_{*}(s,a)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) as follows :

q‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)subscriptùëûùë†ùëé\displaystyle q_{*}(s,a)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =ùîº‚Å¢[Rt+1+Œ≥‚ãÖmaxa‚Ä≤‚Å¢q‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)|St=s,At=a,St+1=s‚Ä≤,At+1=a‚Ä≤]absentùîºdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÖùë°1conditional‚ãÖùõæsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤subscriptùëûsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤subscriptùëÜùë°ùë†formulae-sequencesubscriptùê¥ùë°ùëéformulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜùë°1superscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùê¥ùë°1superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot\underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{% }q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a,~{}~{}S_{t+1}=s^{\prime},A_{t+1}% =a^{\prime}\right]= blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]
=‚àës‚Ä≤,rp‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚ãÖ[r+Œ≥‚ãÖmaxa‚Ä≤‚Å¢q‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)]absentsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëü‚ãÖùëùsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤conditionalùëüùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëü‚ãÖùõæsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤subscriptùëûsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\cdot\left[r+\gamma\cdot% \underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{}{q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})}\right]= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ [ italic_r + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
‚áíq‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)‚áíabsentsubscriptùëûùë†ùëé\displaystyle\Rightarrow q_{*}(s,a)‚áí italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖmaxa‚Ä≤‚Å¢q‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)absentùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤subscriptùëûsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\displaystyle=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot% \underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{}{q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})}= italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
‚áíq‚àó‚Å¢(s,a)‚áíabsentsubscriptùëûùë†ùëé\displaystyle\Rightarrow q_{*}(s,a)‚áí italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖv‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)absentùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot{v_{*}(% s^{\prime})}= italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (3.2.6)

Equations (3.2.5) and (3.2.6) are called Bellman optimality equations. For a finite MDP, the Bellman optimality equation has a unique solution (in the case of infinite MDPs, the Bellman optimality equation may not have a unique solution because infinite MDPs can have multiple optimal policies that lead to the same value function).
And having the optimal value function v‚àósubscriptùë£v_{*}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can determine an optimal policy (because the value function defines a partial order on the policy space).

Finally, even if we have a complete and accurate model of the environment (the dynamics), it is usually not possible to compute an optimal policy simply by solving the Bellman equation. Therefore, approximate methods are developed and used [33].

3.3 Solving Markov Decision Processes

Solving an MDP means try to find an optimal value function v‚àósubscriptùë£v_{*}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or q‚àósubscriptùëûq_{*}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which corresponds to find the optimal policy œÄ‚àósuperscriptùúã\pi^{*}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
There are many ways of doing that, and algorithms were developed for specific challenges. The most used classification consists in distinguishing model-based and model-free algorithms, direct or indirect.
Generally, model-based algorithms concern what is called Dynamic Programming (DP). Model-based algorithms assume that the model of the environment is well known and can be used to find value functions and policies using the Bellman equations.
Model-free algorithms now, is considered as true-RL algorithms. They don‚Äôt require the availability of a perfect model (we suppose that, the environment is not totally known). This method rely on interaction with the environment. That interaction is done by simulating the policy and generating samples of state transitions and rewards. Then, the samples are used to estimate value functions and even to improve the used policy.
In model-free algorithms, since no model of the MDP is known, the agent must explore the MDP to obtain information. This introduces a exploration-exploitation trade-off that must be balanced to obtain an optimal policy.
We can also talk about model-based reinforcement learning algorithms in which the agent does not possess, at the beginning, a model of the environment, but estimates it after a certain amount of time. Once a reasonable model of the environment has been induced, the agent can then apply dynamic programming algorithms to compute the optimal policy.

3.3.1 Dynamic Programming based algorithms or Model-based algorithms

Taking a complex problem, breaking it down into simpler components and solving them recursively is the main idea of dynamic programming.
There are two main Dynamic Programming algorithms from which we can derive others. Policy iteration [17] and value iteration [9]. These two algorithms are based on two principal concepts (policy evaluation and policy improvement) below explained :

  1. 1.

    Policy evaluation :
    The partial order defined by the Relation 3.2.1 gives a way of comparing two policies. Now, by establishing an order between value functions, we can find the best policy. But before doing that, we have to evaluate each specific policy.
    Policy evaluation consists on finding the value function using the function vœÄsubscriptùë£ùúãv_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in Relation 3.1.15 iteratively until convergence. This is done using the following discrete version of the value function :

    vœÄk+1‚Å¢(s)‚üµ‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚ãÖ(r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖvœÄk‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤))‚üµsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùúãùëò1ùë†subscriptùëé‚ãÖùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëòùúãsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤v_{\pi}^{k+1}(s)\longleftarrow\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot% \sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot v^{k}_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\right)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ‚üµ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ‚ãÖ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.1)

    The algorithm 1 below describes how the values of each state are computed iteratively to evaluate the policy [18] :

  2. 2.

    Policy improvement :
    In RL, the final goal is to find the optimal policy. Since the policy space is very huge, the task becomes infeasible. This is why, the policy improvement algorithm, as a solution to that problem, aim to find iteratively the optimal policy, by making small improvements on the current one.
    The idea is to modify the current policy greedily with respect to the value function. But, here we should definitely use the action-value function instead of the state one because the policy is about choosing an action. This will result in a deterministic policy (i.e. the probabilities for each case are 00 or 1111). The only remaining problem is to compute at each time the action-value function but we don‚Äôt have an estimate of it. Fortunately, as we have already a way to get iteratively the state-value function (using policy evaluation), we can now use it in the expression of the action-value function.
    Knowing the relation between qùëûqitalic_q and vùë£vitalic_v, (Relation 3.1.12), we can modify the Expression 3.1.16 as follows :

    qœÄ‚Å¢(s,a)=r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖvœÄ‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)subscriptùëûùúãùë†ùëéùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptùë£ùúãsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤q_{\pi}(s,a)=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot v_{\pi}% (s^{\prime})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (3.3.2)

    So, the algorithm 2 below gives with more details how to improve gradually the policy [18] :

    Now we can look easily on the value iteration and the policy iteration, which are our goals for these Dynamic Programming techniques of solving Markov Decision Processes.

  1. 1.

    Policy iteration :
    Policy iteration is used to find the optimal policy in a Markov decision process (MDP). This algorithm consists of two main steps, policy evaluation and policy improvement. Those two steps are iteratively applied to refine the policy until it converges to the optimal one.

  2. 2.

    Value iteration :
    This value iteration algorithm is like an improvement of policy iteration. In fact, the latter algorithm works effectively and find the optimal policy but it can take a lot of time because at each epoch it computes the policy evaluation and the policy improvement. Value iteration combines policy evaluation and policy improvement into one step. The idea is to replace the general expression of the value function for a given policy (Expression 3.1.15) by the one giving the optimal value function (Expression 3.2.5) in the Expression 3.3.2.

Generally, DP algorithms provide a powerful framework for solving reinforcement learning problems when a perfect model of the environment is known. It decomposes the problem into simpler subproblems and then uses the Bellman equations to compute the value functions. Optimality is reached when the expected cumulative reward is maximised.
Unfortunately, the model of the environment is not always available. Also, DP algorithms can be computationally expensive, especially for problems with large state and action spaces. For those reasons, other RL methods have been developed, such as Monte Carlo methods and temporal difference learning [35].

3.3.2 Model-free algorithms : Monte Carlo

Dynamic Programming (DP) assumes that the agent has a perfect access to the model of the environment (dynamics of the environment). But most of the time, we don‚Äôt have access to that. Additionally, sometimes the state and/or action spaces are very huge in such a way that DP algorithm can be inefficient.
Monte Carlo refers to the method of using experience to estimate value functions by averaging sample returns. Statistically it is proven to converge to the true estimate of the returns [10]. It uses sequences of state-action-reward samples generated by the agent by interacting with the environment.
There are always two important steps to be taken into account, the evaluation step and the improvement step. The idea of Monte Carlo (MC) policy evaluation for example is, following a certain policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ, to generate a sample of state-action-reward-state or state-action-reward-state-action starting from a certain state. After generating a large amount for many episodes (because here we are talking about processes which have a terminating state, i.e. they can end in a finite number of steps), the expected return is obtained by averaging the returns from a large amount of complete sample episodes. This gives the corresponding value for that state, given that specific policy. As the number increases, the average will converges to the true value of vœÄsubscriptùë£ùúãv_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [10].
The previous text just gives a general idea on how MC works. But, there are many implementations of this idea :

  • ‚Ä¢

    First-visit MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • ‚Ä¢

    Every-visit MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • ‚Ä¢

    Incremental MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • ‚Ä¢

    Monte Carlo Control (Monte Carlo Policy Improvement).

Here is a succinct presentation of those main MC approaches :

  1. 1.

    First-visit Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    The idea of this method is to generate a lots of samples, compute the returns at each step within each episode and update the estimate of the state value function for each state (at the end of the considered episode). The update is done by observing whether it is the first time to visit the state in each episode and then update the return and the number of visits. At the end, the expected return will be the average of the returns. What we have just explained is summarised in the following algorithm [18] :

  2. 2.

    Every-visit Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    A visit to a state sùë†sitalic_s is each time the agent passes to that specific state. In the first-visit algorithm, only the first time is considered in each episode while updating the return. For the every-visit, all the visits, even within an episode are taken into account. The former method is unbiased but has an higher variance, the latter is biased with a lower variance. The trade-off is now taken by considering that aspect. Sometime even a combination of them is envisioned. The algorithm comes from a small modification on the one for first-visit [18, 36].

  3. 3.

    Incremental Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    The update method used line 11 of the previous algorithm 3 is still perfectible. In fact, many researches have shown that the incremental updates converges better than the simple update as done in the previous algorithm [18]. So, instead of vœÄ‚Å¢(St)‚üµG‚Å¢(St)/N‚Å¢(St)‚üµsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°ùê∫subscriptùëÜùë°ùëÅsubscriptùëÜùë°v_{\pi}(S_{t})\longleftarrow G(S_{t})/N(S_{t})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµ italic_G ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the incremental approach consists on doing :

    vœÄ‚Å¢(St)‚üµvœÄ‚Å¢(St)+1N‚Å¢(St)‚ãÖ(G‚Å¢(St)‚àívœÄ‚Å¢(St))‚èüincremental error‚üµsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°‚ãÖ1ùëÅsubscriptùëÜùë°incremental error‚èüùê∫subscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°v_{\pi}(S_{t})\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\dfrac{1}{N(S_{t})}\cdot\underset{% \text{incremental error}}{\underbrace{\left(G(S_{t})-v_{\pi}(S_{t})\right)}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ‚ãÖ underincremental error start_ARG under‚èü start_ARG ( italic_G ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG end_ARG (3.3.3)

All these algorithms, can also be used by considering the action-value function instead of the state value function. We just have to change mutatus mutandi everything. For example, for the incremental update shown in Relation 3.3.3, we simply do :

qœÄ‚Å¢(St,At)‚üµqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At)+1N‚Å¢(St,At)‚ãÖ(Gt‚àíqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At))‚üµsubscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°subscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°‚ãÖ1ùëÅsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\dfrac{1}{N(S_{t},A_{t% })}\cdot\Big{(}G_{t}-q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\Big{)}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ‚ãÖ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.4)

Also, exactly as for Dynamic Programming, the control step can be considered. The control step consists now on changing greedily the policy. For this case, there is for example Monte Carlo Control or Policy Improvement. For this, we can even try to do not always choose the best value but combine exploration and exploitation in a good way for better results [40].

3.3.3 Model-free algorithms : Temporal Difference

MC is limited to episodic problems. Temporal Difference (TD) methods generalize MC by dealing with both episodic and continuing (no natural ending or terminating state for the considered task) or infinite RL problems.
So, MC has two main drawbacks : it only takes into account episodic problems and we have to wait for the end of an episode to do any update on the estimated values. This is called Temporal Difference because the agent update its estimates based on the immediate reward and the estimated value for the next state without waiting for the end, even if these values will change another time during the episode. The main idea is a continuous updating of values, a guess from guesses.
Let‚Äôs give the most important implementations which really show how TD works :

  1. 1.

    TD Policy evaluation :
    For a given policy, samples are generated and at the same time incremental update is applied in the following way, without waiting for the end :

    vœÄ‚Å¢(St)subscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle v_{\pi}(S_{t})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµvœÄ‚Å¢(St)+Œª‚ãÖ(Gt‚àívœÄ‚Å¢(St))‚üµabsentsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°‚ãÖùúÜsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(G_{t}-v_{\pi}(S_{% t})\right)‚üµ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œª ‚ãÖ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
    ‚üµvœÄ‚Å¢(St)+Œª‚ãÖ([Rt+Œ≥‚ãÖvœÄ‚Å¢(St+1)]‚àívœÄ‚Å¢(St))‚üµabsentsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°‚ãÖùúÜdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùë°‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\lambda\cdot\Big{(}\left[R_{t}+% \gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+1})\right]-v_{\pi}(S_{t})\Big{)}‚üµ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œª ‚ãÖ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.5)

    We here show the corresponding algorithm :

    If we need to work with action-value functions, we just have to replace vœÄsubscriptùë£ùúãv_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by qœÄsubscriptùëûùúãq_{\pi}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT coherently in equation 1. One obtains :

    qœÄ‚Å¢(St,At)subscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°\displaystyle q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At)+Œª‚ãÖ(Gt‚àíqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At))‚üµabsentsubscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°‚ãÖùúÜsubscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°\displaystyle\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(G_{t}-q_{% \pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\right)‚üµ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œª ‚ãÖ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
    ‚üµqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At)+Œª‚ãÖ([Rt+Œ≥‚ãÖqœÄ‚Å¢(St+1,At+1)]‚àíqœÄ‚Å¢(St,At))‚üµabsentsubscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°‚ãÖùúÜdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùë°‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùê¥ùë°1subscriptùëûùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°\displaystyle\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\Big{(}\left[R_{t% }+\gamma\cdot q_{\pi}(S_{t+1},A_{t+1})\right]-q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\Big{)}‚üµ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œª ‚ãÖ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.6)

    At the end of the algorithm, we‚Äôll update the state as well as the action in case we are using the Expression 1.
    Based on this idea, the update can go far than one step as in the Expression 1. In fact, we can replace Gt=Rt+Œ≥‚ãÖvœÄ‚Å¢(St+1)subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÖùë°‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°1G_{t}=R_{t}+\gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+1})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by Gt=Rt+Œ≥‚ãÖRt+1+‚ãØ+Œ≥n‚ãÖvœÄ‚Å¢(St+n)subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùëÖùë°‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùëÖùë°1‚ãØ‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëõsubscriptùë£ùúãsubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõG_{t}=R_{t}+\gamma\cdot R_{t+1}+\cdots+\gamma^{n}\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+n})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚ãØ + italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Depending on when we stop, it gives us different levels of bootstrapping. This generalizes the TD(0) algorithm we have been illustrating in this part. So, in general we have just an n-step TD Policy Evaluation that we choose to write TD(n) with n+1 the number of steps ahead in the formula [18, 36].

  2. 2.

    TD Control : SARSA
    SARSA stands literally for State-Action-Reward-State-Action. This method uses in fact the general policy iteration template that we have shown in the Dynamic Programming part to find the optimal policy. But it uses specific methods to manage exploration and exploitation while searching for the optimal policy. In fact, from the previous policy iteration that we saw in the DP part, we have to take at each time the one which gives the maximum return (exploitation). But for this case, we can sometimes take a suboptimal action (exploration) with a certain probability ŒµùúÄ\varepsilonitalic_Œµ. This is what we call an Œµ‚Å¢-greedyùúÄ-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_Œµ -greedy selection method.
    Simply, the main idea is to loop on all the states for all the actions (state-action pairs) and then use an Œµ‚Å¢-greedyùúÄ-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_Œµ -greedy policy to select the best action. But note that there are many ways of managing the exploration-exploitation trade-off [18].
    In general also, we can use n-step TD Policy Evaluation in the evaluation part of this policy iteration. It now gives raise to all other implementations of SARSA n-step SARSA [36].

  3. 3.

    TD Control : Q-Learning
    The SARSA algorithm previously introduced is in fact a family of general policy iteration algorithm which estimates the state-action value function qœÄsubscriptùëûùúãq_{\pi}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ and uses an Œµ‚Å¢-greedyùúÄ-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_Œµ -greedy policy to compute a new, better policy œÄ‚Ä≤superscriptùúã‚Ä≤\pi^{\prime}italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But, as we did for value iteration algorithm, we can skip the step of estimating values for a policy œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ by directly making an estimation using the optimal value function formula, so that we‚Äôll be directly estimating the optimal policy. For Q-Learning, we use the same idea by changing the Relation 1 by :

    q‚Å¢(St,At)‚üµq‚Å¢(St,At)+Œª‚ãÖ([Rt+Œ≥‚ãÖm‚Å¢a‚Å¢xa‚Ä≤‚Å¢q‚Å¢(St+1=s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)]‚àíq‚Å¢(St,At))‚üµùëûsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëûsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°‚ãÖùúÜdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùë°‚ãÖùõæsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùëöùëéùë•ùëûsubscriptùëÜùë°1superscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùëûsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê¥ùë°q(S_{t},A_{t})\longleftarrow q(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(\left[R_{t}+% \gamma\cdot\underset{a^{\prime}}{max}~{}q(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime},a^{\prime})\right% ]-q(S_{t},A_{t})\right)italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üµ italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œª ‚ãÖ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG italic_m italic_a italic_x end_ARG italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.7)

    One advantage of this algorithm is that it always uses the maximum value q‚Å¢(St+1,a‚Ä≤)ùëûsubscriptùëÜùë°1superscriptùëé‚Ä≤q(S_{t+1},a^{\prime})italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) across all valid actions for the successor state St+1=s‚Ä≤subscriptùëÜùë°1superscriptùë†‚Ä≤S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, regardless of which action is chosen by the policy.
    We should note that, even if Q-Learning is one of the most used in real-world problems, it may be biased. This is why another method called Double Q-Learning was suggested to alleviate that problem [36, 39].

In many of the tasks the state space is very huge. In such cases, even with the most efficient algorithms we have described above, we cannot expect to find an optimal policy or the optimal value function even in the limit of infinite time and data. Most of the time then, the goal is to find a good approximate of the function we are looking for. Using linear or non-linear approximates. For more information about that, see [18, 30, 36].

Now, as we have seen the main approaches to solve an MDP, which in fact resume the key points of RL foundational algorithms, we can now discuss on how it is related to the fixed point theory.

Chapter Conclusion

In this chapter, we have shown the fundamentals of Reinforcement Learning and how it is connected to Markov Decision Processes. After that, we have discussed about the optimal value functions and optimal policies and then at the end we have shown how generally the optimality is accomplished in RL. The next chapter will now formalize what we have just presented in this chapter as formula to find the optimal policy in terms of operators. This will now allow us to show the connection with the Banach Contraction Principle and how it can help understand deeply why and how RL algorithms work.

Chapter 4 Bellman Operators and Convergence of RL algorithms

In this chapter, we will express reinforcement in terms of operators so that we have a simple way to prove why reinforcement learning algorithms work well and find the optimal policy. To do this, we will first write the Banach contraction principle on normed spaces in a way that makes it easy to use in our next proofs, then we will discuss the Bellman operators, and finally we will talk about the core methods for finding optimality introduced in the previous chapter (but now using the language introduced in this chapter).

4.1 Refinement of the Banach Contraction Principle

We need to state the Banach Contraction Principle presented in the first chapter in such a way that everything in this part will be expressed in the same way, using the same language.

4.1.1 Contraction mapping and fixed-point

Let us now refine everything in term of norms in such a way that we will have a consistent notation until the end of this work. In fact, as we can see in this work, all the concepts related to reinforcement learning are defined in term of norms. So,

4.1.2 Definition.

Let (X,||‚ãÖ||)(X,||\cdot||)( italic_X , | | ‚ãÖ | | ) be a normed space. A mapping ùíØ:X‚ÜíX:ùíØ‚Üíùëãùëã\mathcal{T}:X\rightarrow Xcaligraphic_T : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X is a Œ≥‚àílimit-fromùõæ\gamma-italic_Œ≥ -contraction mapping if, there exists a Œ≥‚àà[0,1)ùõæ01\gamma\in[0,1)italic_Œ≥ ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ) such that, for any x1,x2‚ààXsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùëãx_{1},x_{2}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X we have

‚ÄñùíØ‚Å¢x1‚àíùíØ‚Å¢x2‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñx1‚àíx2‚ÄñnormùíØsubscriptùë•1ùíØsubscriptùë•2‚ãÖùõænormsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2||\mathcal{T}x_{1}-\mathcal{T}x_{2}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{1}-x_{2}||| | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | |

From this, each contraction is Lipchitz and thus continuous [20]. It implies that :

If‚Å¢xn‚Å¢‚ü∂||‚ãÖ||‚Å¢x‚Å¢then‚Å¢ùíØ‚Å¢xn‚Å¢‚ü∂||‚ãÖ||‚Å¢ùíØ‚Å¢x,\text{If}~{}~{}x_{n}\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}x~{}~{}~{}\text{then}% ~{}~{}~{}\mathcal{T}x_{n}\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}\mathcal{T}x,If italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT | | ‚ãÖ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚ü∂ end_ARG italic_x then caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT | | ‚ãÖ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚ü∂ end_ARG caligraphic_T italic_x ,

where ‚ü∂||‚ãÖ||\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}start_UNDERACCENT | | ‚ãÖ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚ü∂ end_ARG denotes the convergence using that norm ||‚ãÖ||||\cdot||| | ‚ãÖ | |. Now, by definition, an element x‚àó‚ààXsuperscriptùë•ùëãx^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X is called fixed point for ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T if we have :

ùíØ‚Å¢x‚àó=x‚àóùíØsuperscriptùë•superscriptùë•\mathcal{T}x^{*}=x^{*}caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
4.1.3 Proposition.

Let (X,||‚ãÖ||)(X,||\cdot||)( italic_X , | | ‚ãÖ | | ) be a Banach space and   ùíØ:X‚ÜíX:ùíØ‚Üíùëãùëã\mathcal{T}:X\rightarrow Xcaligraphic_T : italic_X ‚Üí italic_X    a    Œ≥‚àícontraction mappingùõæcontraction mapping\gamma-\text{contraction mapping}italic_Œ≥ - contraction mapping. Then :

  1. 1.

    ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T has a unique fixed point x‚àó‚ààXsuperscriptùë•ùëãx^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X.

  2. 2.

    For every starting point x0‚ààXsubscriptùë•0ùëãx_{0}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X, the sequence recursively defined by xn+1=ùíØ‚Å¢xnsubscriptùë•ùëõ1ùíØsubscriptùë•ùëõx_{n+1}=\mathcal{T}x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in a geometric fashion.

Proof.

For the first part, see the proof of the Banach fixed point Theorem 2.2.5. Let‚Äôs now only justify the fact that the convergence is in geometric fashion :

ùíØ‚Å¢‚Äñxn‚àí1‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ=‚ÄñùíØ‚Å¢xn‚àí1‚àíùíØ‚Å¢x‚àó‚Äñ=‚ÄñùíØ‚Å¢xn‚àí1‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ=‚Äñxn‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ,ùíØnormsubscriptùë•ùëõ1superscriptùë•normùíØsubscriptùë•ùëõ1ùíØsuperscriptùë•normùíØsubscriptùë•ùëõ1superscriptùë•normsubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•\mathcal{T}||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||=||\mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-\mathcal{T}x^{*}||=||% \mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-x^{*}||=||x_{n}-x^{*}||,caligraphic_T | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ,

and as we are working with a contraction mapping, we also have ‚ÄñùíØ‚Å¢xn‚àí1‚àíùíØ‚Å¢x‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñxn‚àí1‚àíx‚àó‚ÄñnormùíØsubscriptùë•ùëõ1ùíØsuperscriptùë•‚ãÖùõænormsubscriptùë•ùëõ1superscriptùë•||\mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-\mathcal{T}x^{*}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||| | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | |, then we can conclude directly ‚Äñxn‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñxn‚àí1‚àíx‚àó‚Äñnormsubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•‚ãÖùõænormsubscriptùë•ùëõ1superscriptùë•||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||| | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | |. Which implies that we get, by iteratively applying the mapping on the second member of this previous inequality, ‚Äñxn‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥n‚ãÖ‚Äñx0‚àíx‚àó‚Äñnormsubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëõnormsubscriptùë•0superscriptùë•||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\gamma^{n}\cdot||x_{0}-x^{*}||| | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | thus

limn‚Üí‚àû‚Äñxn‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ‚â§limn‚Üí‚àû(Œ≥n‚ãÖ‚Äñx0‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ)=0‚áílimn‚Üí‚àû‚Äñxn‚àíx‚àó‚Äñ=0subscript‚Üíùëõnormsubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•subscript‚Üíùëõ‚ãÖsuperscriptùõæùëõnormsubscriptùë•0superscriptùë•0‚áísubscript‚Üíùëõnormsubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùë•0\lim_{n\to\infty}||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\lim_{n\to\infty}\left(\gamma^{n}\cdot||x_% {0}-x^{*}||\right)=0\Rightarrow\lim_{n\to\infty}||x_{n}-x^{*}||=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ‚â§ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ) = 0 ‚áí roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = 0

‚àé

As we may have noticed, the Proposition 4.1.3, is the Banach Contraction Principle as given by the Theorem 2.2.5. We restrain it on Banach spaces because this is sufficient for the RL setting. In fact, in many instances encountered in Reinforcement Learning (RL), the vector space XùëãXitalic_X is frequently identified as ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or the space of real bounded functions, and the most relevant norms are mostly ||‚ãÖ||2||\cdot||_{2}| | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ||‚ãÖ||‚àû||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So, stating the theorem on Banach Spaces is sufficient in this setting.

4.2 Bellman Optimality Operators

Operators are maps in space of functions. Here we will be defining them with respect to the associated RL equations. Let‚Äôs first define the whole mathematical framework that we‚Äôll be using here.
c
Let ‚Ñ≥=‚ü®ùíÆ,ùíú,p,r,Œ≥‚ü©‚Ñ≥ùíÆùíúùëùùëüùõæ\mathcal{M}=\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},p,r,\gamma\ranglecaligraphic_M = ‚ü® caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_p , italic_r , italic_Œ≥ ‚ü© be a Markov Decision Process (MDP), ùí±s‚â°ùí±subscriptùí±ùë†ùí±\mathcal{V}_{s}\equiv\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° caligraphic_V the space of bounded real-valued functions over ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q the space of bounded real-valued functions over ùíÆ√óùíúùíÆùíú\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}caligraphic_S √ó caligraphic_A. With that we will call :

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V :    the space of all state-value functions,

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q :    the space of all action-value functions,

  • ‚Ä¢

    (ùíØvœÄ):ùí±‚Üíùí±:subscriptsuperscriptùíØùúãùë£‚Üíùí±ùí±\left(\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V ‚Üí caligraphic_V    the Bellman Expectation Operator for the state value function,

  • ‚Ä¢

    (ùíØQœÄ):Q‚ÜíQ:subscriptsuperscriptùíØùúãùëÑ‚ÜíùëÑùëÑ\left(\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{Q}\right):Q\rightarrow Q( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_Q ‚Üí italic_Q :    the Bellman Expectation Operator for the action-value function,

  • ‚Ä¢

    (ùíØv‚àó):ùí±‚Üíùí±:subscriptsuperscriptùíØùë£‚Üíùí±ùí±\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V ‚Üí caligraphic_V    the Bellman Optimality Operator for the state value function,

  • ‚Ä¢

    (ùíØQ‚àó):Q‚ÜíQ:subscriptsuperscriptùíØùëÑ‚ÜíùëÑùëÑ\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{Q}\right):Q\rightarrow Q( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_Q ‚Üí italic_Q :    the Bellman Optimality for the action-value function

  • ‚Ä¢

    œÄ:ùíÆ‚ÜíŒî‚Å¢(ùíú):ùúã‚ÜíùíÆŒîùíú\pi:\mathcal{S}\rightarrow\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)italic_œÄ : caligraphic_S ‚Üí roman_Œî ( caligraphic_A )    the policy (a conditional probability defined by œÄ‚Å¢(a|s)=P‚Å¢r‚Å¢{a|s}ùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùëÉùëüconditional-setùëéùë†\pi(a|s)=Pr\{a|s\}italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r { italic_a | italic_s }) with Œî‚Å¢(ùíú)Œîùíú\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)roman_Œî ( caligraphic_A ) denoting a probability distribution of actions.

Inspired by the definition given in the Expression 2.1.3 and the Example 2.1.14 we know that, with ‚Äñf‚Å¢(s)‚Äñ‚àû‚â°maxùë†‚Å¢|f‚Å¢(s)|subscriptnormùëìùë†ùë†ùëìùë†||f(s)||_{\infty}\equiv\underset{s}{\max}|f(s)|| | italic_f ( italic_s ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_s ) |, the tuple (ùí±,||.||‚àû)(\mathcal{V},||.||_{\infty})( caligraphic_V , | | . | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Banach Space.
Also, with ‚Äñf‚Å¢(s,a)‚Äñ‚àû‚â°maxs,a‚Å¢|f‚Å¢(s,a)|subscriptnormùëìùë†ùëéùë†ùëéùëìùë†ùëé||f(s,a)||_{\infty}\equiv\underset{s,a}{\max}|f(s,a)|| | italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) | we can also see that (ùí¨,||.||‚àû)(\mathcal{Q},||.||_{\infty})( caligraphic_Q , | | . | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Banach Space. Those two supremum norms are different but we will be writing them in the same way because, the real formula will depend on the space we are working with.

4.2.1 Definition.

Let‚Äôs recall the fact that, the Bellman Optimality equation for the value function (Relation 3.2.5) is given by the following expression :

v‚àó‚Å¢(s)=maxùëé‚Å¢(r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖv‚àó‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤))subscriptùë£ùë†ùëéùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤v_{*}(s)=\underset{a}{\max}\Big{(}r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)\cdot v_{*}(s^{\prime})\Big{)}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )

By analogy, we will define, point-wise, the Bellman Optimality Operator for state value function (ùíØv‚àó):ùí±‚Üíùí±:subscriptsuperscriptùíØùë£‚Üíùí±ùí±\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V ‚Üí caligraphic_V by :

(ùíØv‚àó‚Å¢f)‚Å¢(s)‚â°maxùëé‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚ãÖf‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]‚Å¢‚àÄf‚ààùí±subscriptsuperscriptùíØùë£ùëìùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùëìsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤for-allùëìùí±\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}f\right)(s)\equiv\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+% \gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot f(s^{\prime})\right]~{}~{}~% {}\forall f\in\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ‚â° underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ‚ãÖ italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ‚àÄ italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V (4.2.1)

4.2.2 Properties of this operator

The convention we‚Äôll take here is to write (ùíØv‚àó)subscriptsuperscriptùíØùë£\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right)( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) just (ùíØ‚àó)superscriptùíØ\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}\right)( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), knowing that the space will be written ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V by default. Now, what is very interesting is that, the operator, defined in Relation 4.2.1 has these properties [2] :

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùíØ‚àósuperscriptùíØ\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a Œ≥‚àílimit-fromùõæ\gamma-italic_Œ≥ -contraction with respect to the supremum norm ||‚ãÖ||‚àû||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ‚ãÖ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V :

    ‚ÄñùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Äñ‚àû‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñu‚àív‚Äñ‚àû‚Å¢‚àÄu,v‚ààùí±‚Å¢with Œ≥‚àà[0,1)formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscriptùíØùë¢superscriptùíØùë£‚ãÖùõæsubscriptnormùë¢ùë£for-allùë¢ùë£ùí±with Œ≥‚àà[0,1)||\mathcal{T}^{*}u-\mathcal{T}^{*}v||_{\infty}\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}~% {}~{}\forall~{}u,v\in\mathcal{V}~{}~{}~{}\text{with $\gamma\in[0,1)$}| | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àÄ italic_u , italic_v ‚àà caligraphic_V with italic_Œ≥ ‚àà [ 0 , 1 )
  • ‚Ä¢

    ùíØ‚àósuperscriptùíØ\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is monotonic :

    ‚àÄu,v‚ààùí±‚Å¢s.t‚Å¢u‚â§v,in any state,‚Å¢ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚â§ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢vformulae-sequencefor-allùë¢ùë£ùí±s.tùë¢ùë£in any state,superscriptùíØùë¢superscriptùíØùë£\forall~{}u,v\in\mathcal{V}~{}\text{s.t}~{}u\leq v,~{}\text{in any state,}~{}~% {}\mathcal{T}^{*}u\leq\mathcal{T}^{*}v‚àÄ italic_u , italic_v ‚àà caligraphic_V s.t italic_u ‚â§ italic_v , in any state, caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ‚â§ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v
Proof.

First, let us rewrite simply the Bellman Optimality Operator in Relation 4.2.1 like this :

(ùíØv‚àó‚Å¢f)‚Å¢(s)‚â°(ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢f)‚Å¢(s)‚â°maxùëé‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢f‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]subscriptsuperscriptùíØùë£ùëìùë†superscriptùíØùëìùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùëìsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}f\right)(s)\equiv\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}f\right)(s)% \equiv\underset{a}{\max}\Big{[}r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}f(% s^{\prime})\Big{]}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ‚â° ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ‚â° underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] (4.2.2)

Now, let us prove the two properties of the Bellman Optimality Operator ùíØ‚àósuperscriptùíØ\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT :

  1. 1.

    Using the definition of a contraction mapping and Bellman Optimality Operator we expand :

    |ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s)‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s)|=|maxùëé‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]‚àímaxùëè‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(s,b)+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,b‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]|superscriptùíØùë¢ùë†superscriptùíØùë£ùë†ùëédelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëèdelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëè‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëèùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|=\left|\underset{a}{\max}% \left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]-% \underset{b}{\max}\left[r(s,b)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,b}v(s^{% \prime})\right]\right|| caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | = | underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - underitalic_b start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_b ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] |

    Since for f,gùëìùëîf,gitalic_f , italic_g real-valued functions, |maxùë•‚Å¢f‚Å¢(x)‚àímaxùë•‚Å¢g‚Å¢(x)|‚â§maxùë•‚Å¢|f‚Å¢(x)‚àíg‚Å¢(x)|ùë•ùëìùë•ùë•ùëîùë•ùë•ùëìùë•ùëîùë•|\underset{x}{\max}f(x)-\underset{x}{\max}g(x)|\leq\underset{x}{\max}|f(x)-g(x)|| underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_f ( italic_x ) - underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_g ( italic_x ) | ‚â§ underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_g ( italic_x ) |, it follows that :

    |ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s)‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s)|superscriptùíØùë¢ùë†superscriptùíØùë£ùë†\displaystyle\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|| caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ‚â§maxùëé‚Å¢|[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]‚àí[r‚Å¢(s,a)+Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)]|absentùëédelimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùëüùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle\leq\underset{a}{\max}\big{|}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{% s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]-\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{% \prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\right]\big{|}‚â§ underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] |
    =maxùëé‚Å¢|Œ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)‚àíŒ≥‚ãÖùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)|absentùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\big{|}\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u% (s^{\prime})-\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\big{|}= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |
    =maxùëé‚Å¢(Œ≥‚ãÖ|ùîºs‚Ä≤|s,a‚Å¢(u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)‚àív‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤))|)absentùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîºconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëéùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\left(\gamma\cdot\big{|}\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}% |s,a}\left(u(s^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime})\right)\big{|}\right)= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ( italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) | )
    ‚â§maxs‚Ä≤‚Å¢|Œ≥‚ãÖ(u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤)‚àív‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤))|absentsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖùõæùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤\displaystyle\leq\underset{s^{\prime}}{\max}\big{|}\gamma\cdot\left(u(s^{% \prime})-v(s^{\prime})\right)\big{|}‚â§ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    =Œ≥‚ãÖmaxùë†‚Å¢|(u‚Å¢(s)‚àív‚Å¢(s))|absent‚ãÖùõæùë†ùë¢ùë†ùë£ùë†\displaystyle=\gamma\cdot\underset{s}{\max}\big{|}\left(u(s)-v(s)\right)\big{|}= italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s ) - italic_v ( italic_s ) ) |
    ‚áí|ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s)‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s)|‚áíabsentsuperscriptùíØùë¢ùë†superscriptùíØùë£ùë†\displaystyle\Rightarrow\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|‚áí | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñu‚àív‚Äñ‚àûabsent‚ãÖùõæsubscriptnormùë¢ùë£\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
    ‚áímaxùë†‚Å¢|ùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s)‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s)|‚áíabsentùë†superscriptùíØùë¢ùë†superscriptùíØùë£ùë†\displaystyle\Rightarrow\underset{s}{\max}\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T% }^{*}v(s)\right|‚áí underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñu‚àív‚Äñ‚àûabsent‚ãÖùõæsubscriptnormùë¢ùë£\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
    ‚áí‚ÄñùíØ‚àó‚Å¢u‚Å¢(s)‚àíùíØ‚àó‚Å¢v‚Å¢(s)‚Äñ‚àû‚áíabsentsubscriptnormsuperscriptùíØùë¢ùë†superscriptùíØùë£ùë†\displaystyle\Rightarrow||\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)||_{\infty}‚áí | | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñu‚àív‚Äñ‚àûabsent‚ãÖùõæsubscriptnormùë¢ùë£\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (4.2.3)
  2. 2.

    We can now prove the monotonicity very simply :

    Assume that for all sùë†sitalic_s, v‚Å¢(s)‚â§u‚Å¢(s)ùë£ùë†ùë¢ùë†v(s)\leq u(s)italic_v ( italic_s ) ‚â§ italic_u ( italic_s ).
