    |limk‚Üí‚àû[Qk,ùíØb‚àíVk,ùíØb]|=0‚â§|limk‚Üí‚àû[Qk,ùíØa‚àíVk,ùíØa]|subscript‚Üíùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëÑùëòsubscriptùíØùëèsubscriptùëâùëòsubscriptùíØùëè0subscript‚Üíùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëÑùëòsubscriptùíØùëésubscriptùëâùëòsubscriptùíØùëé\left|\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\left[Q_{k,\mathcal{T}_{b}}-V_{k,\mathcal{T}_{b}% }\right]\right|=0~{}~{}~{}~{}\leq~{}~{}~{}~{}\left|\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}% \left[Q_{k,\mathcal{T}_{a}}-V_{k,\mathcal{T}_{a}}\right]\right|| roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] | = 0 ‚â§ | roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] |

    For other actions, the inequality also holds because on convergence (Qk‚àí1‚àíVk‚àí1)<0subscriptùëÑùëò1subscriptùëâùëò10\left(Q_{k-1}-V_{k-1}\right)<0( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < 0 almost surely and from the proof of optimality preservation we have seen that :

    B‚Å¢e‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢(Qk‚àí1)+Œ≤‚ãÖ(Qk‚àí1‚àíVk‚àí1)<‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚ãÖB‚Å¢e‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢(Qk‚àí1)+Œ≤‚ãÖ‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚ãÖ(Qk‚àí1‚àíVk‚àí1),ùêµùëíùëôùëôsubscriptùëÑùëò1‚ãÖùõΩsubscriptùëÑùëò1subscriptùëâùëò1subscriptùëé‚ãÖùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùêµùëíùëôùëôsubscriptùëÑùëò1‚ãÖùõΩsubscriptùëé‚ãÖùúãconditionalùëéùë†subscriptùëÑùëò1subscriptùëâùëò1Bell\left(Q_{k-1}\right)+\beta\cdot\left(Q_{k-1}-V_{k-1}\right)<\sum_{a}\pi(a|% s)\cdot Bell\left(Q_{k-1}\right)+\beta\cdot\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(Q_{k-1}-% V_{k-1}\right),italic_B italic_e italic_l italic_l ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œ≤ ‚ãÖ ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ‚ãÖ italic_B italic_e italic_l italic_l ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œ≤ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) ‚ãÖ ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , i.e. also |limk‚Üí‚àû[Qk,ùíØb‚àíVk,ùíØb]|‚â§|limk‚Üí‚àû[Qk,ùíØa‚àíVk,ùíØa]|subscript‚Üíùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëÑùëòsubscriptùíØùëèsubscriptùëâùëòsubscriptùíØùëèsubscript‚Üíùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëÑùëòsubscriptùíØùëésubscriptùëâùëòsubscriptùíØùëé\left|\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\left[Q_{k,\mathcal{T}_{b}}-V_{k,\mathcal{T}_{b}% }\right]\right|\leq\left|\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\left[Q_{k,\mathcal{T}_{a}}-V% _{k,\mathcal{T}_{a}}\right]\right|| roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] | ‚â§ | roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] | for any (s,a)‚ààùíÆ√óùíúùë†ùëéùíÆùíú(s,a)\in\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_s , italic_a ) ‚àà caligraphic_S √ó caligraphic_A.

‚àé

So, the operator that we suggested through the Expression 5.1.6 is a well behaving operator, even if we just assume the convergence (modulo the value of Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤).
Let us now give some comments about the possibility of finding a fixed point for this operator. But, before doing so, we can first say something about the continuity and the boundedness of that operator because without that, we cannot talk about fixed points.

5.1.8 Proposition.

Let r‚Å¢(s,a)ùëüùë†ùëér(s,a)italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ), the reward function, be bounded and continuous. The operator ùíØasubscriptùíØùëé\mathcal{T}_{a}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as defined by the Expression 5.1.6, will also be bounded and continuous.

Proof.

We can split our operator in three parts for simplicity :

(ùíØa‚Å¢f)=r‚Å¢(s,a)‚èüpart 1+Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚Å¢(‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ‚Å¢(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖf‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))‚èüpart 2+Œ≤‚ãÖ[f‚Å¢(s,a)‚àí‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(s,a)]‚èüA‚Å¢(s,a)‚Å¢: advantage learning :: part 3subscriptùíØùëéùëìpart 1‚èüùëüùë†ùëépart 2‚èü‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùúãconditionalsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëìsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùê¥ùë†ùëé: advantage learning :: part 3‚èü‚ãÖùõΩdelimited-[]ùëìùë†ùëésubscriptùëéùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùëìùë†ùëé\left(\mathcal{T}_{a}f\right)=\underset{\text{part 1}}{\underbrace{r(s,a)}}+% \underset{\text{part 2}}{\underbrace{\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|% s,a)\left(\sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot f(s^{\prime},a^{% \prime})\right)}}+\underset{A(s,a)\text{:~{}advantage learning :: part 3}}{% \underbrace{\beta\cdot\left[f(s,a)-\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)f(s,a)\right]}}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) = underpart 1 start_ARG under‚èü start_ARG italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) end_ARG end_ARG + underpart 2 start_ARG under‚èü start_ARG italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG end_ARG + start_UNDERACCENT italic_A ( italic_s , italic_a ) : advantage learning :: part 3 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG under‚èü start_ARG italic_Œ≤ ‚ãÖ [ italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) ] end_ARG end_ARG
  1. 1.

    Part 1 : the reward function is assumed to be continuous and bounded.

  2. 2.

    Part 2 : If we take that part as an operator by itself, it will be bounded (because it is a contraction) and also linear. And being a bounded linear operator implies that it is also continuous. So, if we call this new operator ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢lsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëô\mathcal{T}_{small}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT written as follows :

    (ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢f)‚Å¢(s,a)=Œ≥‚ãÖ‚àës‚Ä≤p‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚Å¢(‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ‚Å¢(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖf‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))=Œ≥‚ãÖùîº‚Ñô‚Å¢(‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ‚Å¢(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖf‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)),subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùëìùë†ùëé‚ãÖùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë†ùëésubscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùúãconditionalsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëìsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîº‚Ñôsubscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùúãconditionalsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëìsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\Big{(}\mathcal{T}_{small}f\Big{)}(s,a)=\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)\left(\sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot f(s^{\prime% },a^{\prime})\right)=\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sum_{a^{\prime}}% \pi(a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot f(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})\right),( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ,

    We can firstly prove the linearity, assuming that u,v‚ààùí¨ùë¢ùë£ùí¨u,v\in\mathcal{Q}italic_u , italic_v ‚àà caligraphic_Q and Œ±,Œ≤‚àà‚ÑùùõºùõΩ‚Ñù\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{R}italic_Œ± , italic_Œ≤ ‚àà blackboard_R. We have to show that

    ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢(Œ±‚ãÖu+Œ≤‚ãÖv)=Œ±‚ãÖùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢u+Œ≤‚ãÖùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢vsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëô‚ãÖùõºùë¢‚ãÖùõΩùë£‚ãÖùõºsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë¢‚ãÖùõΩsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë£\mathcal{T}_{small}\Big{(}\alpha\cdot u+\beta\cdot v\Big{)}=\alpha\cdot% \mathcal{T}_{small}~{}u+\beta\cdot\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}vcaligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ italic_u + italic_Œ≤ ‚ãÖ italic_v ) = italic_Œ± ‚ãÖ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u + italic_Œ≤ ‚ãÖ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v

    And, that is true because the operator is just formed with average operations, which are in fact linear. So, ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢lsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëô\mathcal{T}_{small}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is linear.
    Let‚Äôs now prove the contraction. For that, using again uùë¢uitalic_u and vùë£vitalic_v defined previously, we have :

    |ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢u‚àíùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢v|subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë¢subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë£\displaystyle\Big{|}\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}u-\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}v\Big{|}| caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | =|Œ≥‚ãÖùîº‚Ñô‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖ(u(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àív(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))|\displaystyle=\Big{|}\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}\sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^% {\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot\left(u(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime},a^{\prime% })\right)\Big{|}= | italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖùîº‚Ñô|‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖ(u(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àív(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))|\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}\Big{|}\sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi% (a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot\left(u(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime},a^{% \prime})\right)\Big{|}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖùîº‚Ñô‚Å¢‚àëa‚Ä≤œÄ‚Å¢(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)‚ãÖ|(u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àív‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))|absent‚ãÖùõæsubscriptùîº‚Ñôsubscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤‚ãÖùúãconditionalsuperscriptùëé‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}\sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^{% \prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot\Big{|}\left(u(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime},a^{% \prime})\right)\Big{|}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ | ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖmaxs‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤‚Å¢|(u‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àív‚Å¢(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤))|absent‚ãÖùõæsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùë¢superscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùë†‚Ä≤superscriptùëé‚Ä≤\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot\underset{s^{\prime},a^{\prime}}{\max}\Big{|}\left% (u(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})\right)\Big{|}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    =Œ≥‚ãÖmaxs,a‚Å¢|(u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))|absent‚ãÖùõæùë†ùëéùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëé\displaystyle=\gamma\cdot\underset{s,a}{\max}\Big{|}\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)\right)% \Big{|}= italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) |
    ‚áí|ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢u‚àíùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢v|‚áíabsentsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë¢subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë£\displaystyle\Rightarrow\Big{|}\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}u-\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}v% \Big{|}‚áí | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖmaxs,a‚Å¢|(u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))|absent‚ãÖùõæùë†ùëéùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëé\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot\underset{s,a}{\max}\Big{|}\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)% \right)\Big{|}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) |
    ‚áímaxs,a‚Å¢|ùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢u‚àíùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢v|‚áíabsentùë†ùëésubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë¢subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë£\displaystyle\Rightarrow\underset{s,a}{\max}\Big{|}\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}u-% \mathcal{T}_{small}~{}v\Big{|}‚áí start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖmaxs,a‚Å¢|(u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))|absent‚ãÖùõæùë†ùëéùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëé\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot\underset{s,a}{\max}\Big{|}\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)% \right)\Big{|}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) |
    ‚áí‚ÄñùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢u‚àíùíØs‚Å¢m‚Å¢a‚Å¢l‚Å¢l‚Å¢v‚Äñ‚àû‚áíabsentsubscriptnormsubscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë¢subscriptùíØùë†ùëöùëéùëôùëôùë£\displaystyle\Rightarrow||\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}u-\mathcal{T}_{small}~{}v||_{\infty}‚áí | | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_m italic_a italic_l italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§Œ≥‚ãÖ‚Äñ(u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))‚Äñ‚àûabsent‚ãÖùõæsubscriptnormùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëé\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)\right)||_{\infty}‚â§ italic_Œ≥ ‚ãÖ | | ( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (5.1.9)

    Thus, the second part is also continuous and bounded.

  3. 3.

    Part 3 : We know that, if fùëìfitalic_f is continuous and bounded, then f‚Å¢(s,a)‚àí‚àëaœÄ‚Å¢(a|s)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(s,a)ùëìùë†ùëésubscriptùëéùúãconditionalùëéùë†ùëìùë†ùëéf(s,a)-\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)f(s,a)italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ ( italic_a | italic_s ) italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) will also be continuous and bounded. We just need to ensure that Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ has good properties, ensuring convergence.

Finally, knowing that the summation of continuous and bounded operators is also continuous and bounded, we have proved the assertion, and ùíØasubscriptùíØùëé\mathcal{T}_{a}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is continuous and bounded (the notion of good behavior for Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ is just to be precised). ‚àé

From the fact that ùíØasubscriptùíØùëé\mathcal{T}_{a}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is continuous and bounded (modulo the behavior of Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤), we are sure that it will not diverge if we set well the values of Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤. And, looking carefully on that operator, we can now say something about Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤.
We will always need an operator which is well behaving (improving speed and optimality) but also close enough to the classical Bellman Operator as we are evolving. That is the only way we can ensure that we will get closer enough to the same fixed point while maintaining some nice properties of this alternative operator.
If now we consider a family of operators based on ùíØasubscriptùíØùëé\mathcal{T}_{a}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by varying Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤, and the case of a Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ which changes per iteration in one operator during the learning process, to ensure convergence, they should fulfill the following conditions :

{‚àëj=1‚àûŒ≤i,j<‚àû{Œ≤i,j}‚Üí0‚Å¢with j fixed.‚Å¢i : the operator, j : iterationcasessuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùõΩùëñùëómissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsubscriptùõΩùëñùëó‚Üí0with j fixed.i : the operator, j : iteration\left\{\begin{array}[]{lcl}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\infty}\beta_{i,j}&<&\infty\\ &&\\ \{\beta_{i,j}\}&\to&0~{}~{}~{}\text{with $j$ fixed.}\end{array}\right.~{}~{}% \text{$i$ : the operator,~{}~{} $j$ : iteration}{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL < end_CELL start_CELL ‚àû end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL { italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_CELL start_CELL ‚Üí end_CELL start_CELL 0 with italic_j fixed. end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY italic_i : the operator, italic_j : iteration (5.1.10)

For an operator which has a varying Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ across training, as it will be applied iteratively, we can directly notice that after many iterations, we will have some terms like this

‚àëŒ≤i,j‚ãÖ(u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))j‚â°‚àëŒ≤i,j‚ãÖAj,‚ãÖsubscriptùõΩùëñùëósubscriptùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëéùëó‚ãÖsubscriptùõΩùëñùëósubscriptùê¥ùëó\sum\beta_{i,j}\cdot\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)\right)_{j}\equiv\sum\beta_{i,j}\cdot A% _{j},‚àë italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° ‚àë italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and as the difference (u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))jsubscriptùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëéùëó\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)\right)_{j}( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded, we can replace it by its bound. Let‚Äôs call the bound of (u‚Å¢(s,a)‚àív‚Å¢(s,a))j‚â°Ajsubscriptùë¢ùë†ùëéùë£ùë†ùëéùëósubscriptùê¥ùëó\left(u(s,a)-v(s,a)\right)_{j}\equiv A_{j}( italic_u ( italic_s , italic_a ) - italic_v ( italic_s , italic_a ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT simply Aùê¥Aitalic_A. Then :

‚àëŒ≤i,j‚ãÖAj‚â§A‚ãÖ‚àëjŒ≤i,j<‚àû‚áî‚àëjŒ≤i,j<‚àûiff‚ãÖsubscriptùõΩùëñùëósubscriptùê¥ùëó‚ãÖùê¥subscriptùëósubscriptùõΩùëñùëósubscriptùëósubscriptùõΩùëñùëó\sum\beta_{i,j}\cdot A_{j}\leq A\cdot\sum_{j}\beta_{i,j}<\infty\iff\sum_{j}% \beta_{i,j}<\infty‚àë italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_A ‚ãÖ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû ‚áî ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû

So, for one operator, with varying Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ across iterations, the sum of values should be finite.
Also, with the conditions we gave, it allows us to construct directly a sequence of operators converging to the classical Bellman Operator. So, that‚Äôs why we need :

{Œ≤i,j}‚Üí0‚Å¢with j fixed.‚ÜísubscriptùõΩùëñùëó0with j fixed.\{\beta_{i,j}\}\to 0~{}~{}~{}\text{with $j$ fixed.}{ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ‚Üí 0 with italic_j fixed.
5.1.9 Example.

One example of a family of operators with the form given by the Expression 5.1.6 and fulfilling the conditions on Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ given by 5.1.10, can be :

  1. 1.

    Operator 1 : Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ is a sequence given by {Œ≤1,j}subscriptùõΩ1ùëó\{\beta_{1,j}\}{ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with Œ≤1,j=1j2subscriptùõΩ1ùëó1superscriptùëó2\beta_{1,j}=\dfrac{1}{j^{2}}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

  2. 2.

    Operator 2 : Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ is a sequence given by {Œ≤2,j}subscriptùõΩ2ùëó\{\beta_{2,j}\}{ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with Œ≤2,j=1j3subscriptùõΩ2ùëó1superscriptùëó3\beta_{2,j}=\dfrac{1}{j^{3}}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

  3. 3.

    Operator kùëòkitalic_k : Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ is a sequence given by {Œ≤k,j}subscriptùõΩùëòùëó\{\beta_{k,j}\}{ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with Œ≤k,j=1jk+1subscriptùõΩùëòùëó1superscriptùëóùëò1\beta_{k,j}=\dfrac{1}{j^{k+1}}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

As last comment on this part we can observe : during our diverse proofs, we just require to the mappings to be contractions and monotonic in order to establish the existence of an optimal fixed point. The use of specific definitions of value functions was not really important. This is why we can conjecture that :

5.1.10 Conjecture.

Any monotonic contraction mapping integreting a certain notion of policy is a suitable candidate as operator in Reinforcement Learning (we just have to refine accordingly the definitions of the associated value functions for them to be suitable to the RL framework).

5.2 Practical implementation and analysis

To prove the effectiveness of the suggested Modified Robust Stochastic Operator, we have conducted experiments on 3 groups of classical problems in reinforcement learning using the Q-Learning algorithm, in Open-AI Gymnasium environments. The implementation of Q-Learning we used is inspired by [41] and our own implementation with all the parameters is in our Github Repository [1].
Here are the necessary details on the environments we used :

5.2.1 Environments and results

  • 1.

    Mountain Car environment : The theory about this environment is presented in [25]. The state vector is 2-dimensional, continuous with a total of three possible actions. As long as the goal is not yet reached, depending on the action, a negative reward is given to the agent, until it reaches the goal. Following [23], we have discretized the state space into a 40√ó40404040\times 4040 √ó 40 grid, but differently we did 10000 training steps, with 10000 episodes each. The following Figure 5.1 shows the averages across episodes.

  • 2.

    Cart Pole environment : The theory about Cart Pole is presented in [7]. The state vector is 4-dimensional and continuous with a total of two possible actions. The aim is to keep the pole upright for as long as possible, with a reward of +11+1+ 1 for each step up to the failure, including the final step. So, the reward is positive at the end. Here, we have discretized the state space into a 150√ó150√ó150√ó150150150150150150\times 150\times 150\times 150150 √ó 150 √ó 150 √ó 150 grid and again we did 10000 training steps, with 10000 episodes each. The following Figure 5.2 shows the averages across episodes.

  • 3.

    Acrobot environment : The theory about Acrobot is presented in [35]. The state vector is 6-dimensional and continuous with a total of three possible actions. The goal is to have the free end of the Acrobot to reach the target height (represented by a horizontal line) in as few steps as possible, with each step not reaching the target being rewarded with -1. So, the reward is negative again as for Mountain Car. Here, we have discretized the state space into a 30√ó30√ó30√ó30√ó30√ó3030303030303030\times 30\times 30\times 30\times 30\times 3030 √ó 30 √ó 30 √ó 30 √ó 30 √ó 30 grid, due to the limitations in memory allocation of the computer we was using, and again we did 10000 training steps, with 10000 episodes each. The following Figure 5.3 shows the averages across episodes.

5.2.2 Interpretation and discussion

  • 1.

    Mountain Car : From the problem presented above, we know that the reward for mountain car can be negative because it depends with how long the agent takes to reach the goal or to be stopped. Now, looking on the Figure 5.1 we can directly see how the average reward is better using the Modified Robust Stochastic Operator than using the Bellman Operator. Also, the classical and the consistent operators are performing exactly the same for this specific case. So, overall, the suggested Operator finishes the episodes with higher reward than for the other two operators (the classical and the consistent).

  • 2.

    Cart Pole : For Cart Pole, we can see in Figure 5.2 that the higher reward is reached again while using the Modified Bellman (suggested Bellman) compared to the other operators. And the difference in terms of performances is really clear.

  • 3.

    Acrobot : Acrobot was more challenging and as we can see in Figure 5.3, the results using those 3 operators are about the same. So, we think this is due to the fact that we were not able to make a finer discretization for the Acrobot environment. In fact this was due to the memory limitations. So, this experiment needs further investigations to establish clearly what is the great attainable difference between those operators.

So, generally we can say that the Consistent Bellman Operator gives about the same result as the classical one, but our modified version of the Robust Stochastic Operator gives most of the time better results comparing to the other previous two operators.

Chapter Conclusion

In this last chapter, we have introduced the Consistent Bellman Operator as the first alternative to the classical Bellman Operator presented in the previous chapter, and we showed that it fulfills exactly the same properties as the classical one (uniqueness of the optimal fixed point), although this raises the question of the relation between a fixed point found by the Consistent Bellman and the one we can find by the classical Bellman. Secondly, we presented our version of the robust stochastic operator. We modified the one proposed in the literature in such a way that it no longer needs stochasticity, but still preserves some good properties (gap increasing and optimality preservation), even if it loses the properties of a classical Bellman operator. Finally, with results from a practical implementation, we clearly show that our proposed operator must be taken seriously, since it unexpectedly outperforms the classical Bellman operator on some difficult tasks, as hypothesised.

Chapter 6 Conclusion

This work serves as a foundational effort in the deep and precise mathematical study of Reinforcement Learning concepts. The aim is to facilitate breakthrough discoveries and subsequent investigations, and to enable even pure mathematicians to contribute to this subject by suggesting insightful adjustments necessary for improving Reinforcement Learning algorithms. This has been achieved through the various chapters in this work as follows:

After the general introduction, in Chapter 2, we primarily discussed contraction mappings in a metric space and the Banach Fixed Point Theorem. We also demonstrated how the Banach Fixed Point Theorem can be used to prove the existence and uniqueness of solutions to first-order Ordinary Differential Equations with initial conditions.

In Chapter 3, we expressed the Reinforcement Learning problem in terms of a Markov Decision Process. This allowed us to introduce different expressions of the value function, both in terms of state and state-action pairs. Subsequently, we presented the concepts of Bellman Equations, which served as the first step in introducing the Bellman Operators.

Chapter 4 was dedicated to Bellman Operators. We have demonstrated that these operators are Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥-contraction and monotonic mappings, implying that they have a unique fixed point that is the optimum. This justification sheds light on why and how Reinforcement Learning algorithms work from a fundamental perspective.

At the end, in chapter 5, we presented the Consistent Bellman Operator as the first alternative to the classical Bellman Operator. After that, we showed that it fulfills exactly the same properties as the classical Bellman Operator (uniqueness of the optimal fixed point). However, this raised questions about the relationship between a fixed point found through the Consistent Bellman Operator and one found through the classical Operator. We then introduced a modification of the Robust Stochastic Operator, which is deterministic but defined in a more general and precise way. This demonstrates that stochasticity is no longer necessary to achieve better results than the classical Bellman Operator. Finally, using an implementation in Python and OpenAI Gymnasium environments, we clearly demonstrated that our proposed operator merits serious consideration, as it outperforms the classical Bellman Operator in many of the considered tasks.

Based on the foundations laid by this work, the perspectives are numerous. The mathematical properties of value function spaces have been clearly presented (value functions can indeed be properly studied in Banach spaces), but future researchers can explore in depth the state space and the action space as well as the policy space. They can also extend the analysis of the efficiency of our proposed operator. The most relevant attempts we have seen during our research are in [12], where the geometric and topological properties of value functions for Markov decision processes are explored, and in [21], where a unified formalism for defining state similarity metrics in Reinforcement Learning is introduced, hierarchies among metrics are established, and their implications for Reinforcement Learning algorithms are studied. We expect that these can be well understood and extended with the help of the investigations done in this work.

This work enables researchers, even those not currently involved in the field, to quickly and meaningfully engage with Reinforcement Learning, as the most important foundations are mathematically clarified.

\endappendix

Report Github Issue
Generated by L A T E xml

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
